flashCards.title: Instruction Following Model
flashCards.definition: AI system designed to execute tasks based on specific commands or instructions provided by users.

flashCards.title: Wake Sleep
flashCards.definition: Biologically inspired algorithm used within unsupervised learning to train deep belief networks.

flashCards.title: Next Word Prediction
flashCards.definition: Enables language models to predict the most probable subsequent word in a text sequence using generative AI techniques.

flashCards.title: Vector Operation
flashCards.definition: Essential mathematical operations on vectors used for computations in AI to facilitate algorithms in data representation, transformation, and manipulation.

flashCards.title: Agent
flashCards.definition: System capable of perceiving its environment through sensors and acting upon that environment to achieve specific goals.

flashCards.title: Invariance
flashCards.definition: Property of a model or algorithm that ensures its output remains unchanged when specific transformations are applied to the input data.

flashCards.title: Surprise
flashCards.definition: Measuring the degree of unexpectedness or novelty in AI systems.

flashCards.title: Misuse
flashCards.definition: Application of AI technologies in ways that are unethical, illegal, or harmful to individuals or society.

flashCards.title: Affective Computation
flashCards.definition: Field within AI that focuses on the design of systems and devices capable of recognizing, interpreting, processing, and simulating human emotions.

flashCards.title: Decomposition
flashCards.definition: Process of breaking down a complex problem into smaller, more manageable parts that can be solved individually.

flashCards.title: Ontology
flashCards.definition: Structured framework that categorizes and organizes information or data into a hierarchy of concepts and relationships, facilitating the sharing and reuse of knowledge across systems and domains.

flashCards.title: Kernel Method
flashCards.definition: A set of algorithms that enable machine learning models to perform in high-dimensional spaces without directly computing those dimensions.

flashCards.title: NLD (Neural Lie Detectors)
flashCards.definition: AI systems designed to identify dishonesty or inconsistencies in the outputs or decisions of other AI models by analyzing their responses or behavior.

flashCards.title: Conditional Generation
flashCards.definition: Process where models produce output based on specified conditions or constraints.

flashCards.title: Self-Reasoning Token
flashCards.definition: AI mechanism designed to enhance the planning capabilities of language models by allowing them to anticipate and prepare for future outputs.

flashCards.title: Noise
flashCards.definition: Irrelevant or meaningless data in a dataset or unwanted variations in signals that can interfere with the training and performance of AI models.

flashCards.title: DoLa (Decoding by Contrasting Layers)
flashCards.definition: Novel method for enhancing language model performance by focusing on contrasting the outputs of different layers to improve decoding accuracy.

flashCards.title: AI Failure Modes
flashCards.definition: Diverse scenarios where AI systems do not perform as expected or generate unintended consequences.

flashCards.title: Generalization
flashCards.definition: Ability of a ML model to perform well on new, unseen data that was not included in the training set.

flashCards.title: Intelligence Explosion
flashCards.definition: Hypothetical scenario where an AI system rapidly improves its own capabilities and intelligence, leading to a superintelligent AI far surpassing human intelligence.

flashCards.title: Syntactic Templates
flashCards.definition: Predefined structures that define the permissible syntax patterns for sentences in natural language processing (NLP) to facilitate parsing and generation tasks.

flashCards.title: Empathic AI
flashCards.definition: AI systems designed to recognize, understand, and respond to human emotions in a nuanced and contextually appropriate manner.

flashCards.title: Sampling
flashCards.definition: Fundamental technique used to reduce computational cost and simplify data management

flashCards.title: Shared Awareness
flashCards.definition: Collective understanding and perception of information among multiple agents, both human and machine, in a given environment.

flashCards.title: Cosine Similarity
flashCards.definition: Measures the cosine of the angle between two vectors in a multidimensional space, often used to determine how similar two items are.

flashCards.title: Capsule Networks
flashCards.definition: Type of artificial neural network designed to improve the processing of spatial hierarchical information by encoding data into small groups of neurons called capsules.

flashCards.title: Gorilla Program
flashCards.definition: Concept in AI that illustrates the potential risk of superintelligent machines surpassing human control.

flashCards.title: Fast Takeoff
flashCards.definition: Rapid transition from human-level to superintelligent AI, occurring in a very short period of time.

flashCards.title: Matrix Models
flashCards.definition: Mathematical frameworks that use matrices with parameters to represent and solve complex problems, often in ML, statistics, and systems theory.

flashCards.title: Association Rule
flashCards.definition: Method in data mining for discovering interesting relationships, patterns, or correlations among a large set of data items.

flashCards.title: SSL (Self-Supervised Learning)
flashCards.definition: Type of ML where the system learns to predict part of its input from other parts, using its own data structure as supervision.

flashCards.title: Log Likelihood
flashCards.definition: Logarithm of the likelihood function, used in statistical models to measure how well a model explains a given set of data.

flashCards.title: Full-Sequence Diffusion
flashCards.definition: Approach in diffusion models where the entire sequence of data undergoes the diffusion process simultaneously rather than segment by segment.

flashCards.title: Tree of Thought
flashCards.definition: A cognitive framework within AI that models decision-making processes using tree-like structures to simulate human-like reasoning and planning.

flashCards.title: SLM (Sparse Linear Model)
flashCards.definition: Predictive model that uses a sparse representation of the underlying data to make accurate predictions.

flashCards.title: Model Level
flashCards.definition: Abstraction layer at which an AI or ML model operates, focusing on the specific details and mechanics of the model's architecture and functioning.

flashCards.title: Permutation
flashCards.definition: Arrangement of all or part of a set of objects in a specific order.

flashCards.title: Sovereign AI
flashCards.definition: Hypothetical form of AI that operates independently with its own autonomy, potentially possessing the ability to make decisions and take actions without human intervention.

flashCards.title: Model Distillation
flashCards.definition: ML technique where a larger, more complex model (teacher) is used to train a smaller, simpler model (student) to approximate the teacher's predictions while maintaining similar performance.

flashCards.title: Ensemble Methods
flashCards.definition: ML technique where multiple models are trained and used collectively to solve a problem.

flashCards.title: Shors Algorithm
flashCards.definition: A quantum algorithm that efficiently solves integer factorization, potentially threatening classical encryption systems.

flashCards.title: Cognitive Computing
flashCards.definition: Computer systems that simulate human thought processes to solve complex problems.

flashCards.title: Self-Awareness
flashCards.definition: Nn entity's ability to recognize itself as an individual, distinct from its environment and other entities, often involving introspection and a sense of identity.

flashCards.title: AMI (Advanced Machine Intelligence)
flashCards.definition: Refers to high-level AI systems possessing the capability to perform complex cognitive tasks with or without human-like reasoning.

flashCards.title: Conditional Probability
flashCards.definition: Measures the likelihood of an event occurring, given that another event has already occurred.

flashCards.title: Bias-Variance Trade-off
flashCards.definition: In ML, achieving optimal model performance involves balancing bias and variance to minimize overall error.

flashCards.title: Contextual Embedding
flashCards.definition: Vector representations of words or tokens in a sentence that capture their meanings based on the surrounding context, enabling dynamic and context-sensitive understanding of language.

flashCards.title: DAG (Directed Acyclic Graphs)
flashCards.definition: Graph that consists of vertices connected by edges, with the directionality from one vertex to another and no possibility of forming a cycle.

flashCards.title: Inductive Reasoning
flashCards.definition: Logical process where specific observations or instances are used to form broader generalizations and theories.

flashCards.title: Brain Organoid Reservoir Computing
flashCards.definition: Combines the use of brain organoids—3D cultures of human brain cells—with reservoir computing principles to create advanced computational models for studying neural dynamics and intelligence.

flashCards.title: Control Problem
flashCards.definition: Challenge of ensuring that highly advanced AI systems act in alignment with human values and intentions.

flashCards.title: Intention
flashCards.definition: Planned or desired outcome that an agent aims to achieve through its actions.

flashCards.title: Data Blending
flashCards.definition: Process of combining data from multiple sources into a single, cohesive dataset for analysis.

flashCards.title: Natural Language
flashCards.definition: Any language that has developed naturally among humans, used for everyday communication, such as English, Mandarin, or Spanish.

flashCards.title: Image-to-Text Model
flashCards.definition: AI systems that convert visual information from images into descriptive textual representations, enabling machines to understand and communicate the content of images.

flashCards.title: Word Salad
flashCards.definition: Disorganized and nonsensical sequence of words or letters, often making it difficult or impossible to derive coherent meaning from the text.

flashCards.title: BQL (Binary Quantization Learning)
flashCards.definition: ML method that aims to reduce model complexity and computational cost by quantizing weights and activations to binary values.

flashCards.title: Flexible Semantics
flashCards.definition: Ability of a system to adapt and interpret meaning in a dynamic, context-sensitive manner, particularly within language processing and understanding.

flashCards.title: Retrieval-Based Model
flashCards.definition: Algorithms that generate responses by selecting them from a predefined set of responses, based on the input they receive.

flashCards.title: Kaleidoscope Hypothesis
flashCards.definition: Approach in AI that focuses on the dynamic and context-specific evaluation of machine learning models, particularly in settings where model behavior must adapt to varying real-world conditions.

flashCards.title: Transformer
flashCards.definition: Deep learning model architecture designed for handling sequential data, especially effective in natural language processing tasks.

flashCards.title: Counterfactual Explanations
flashCards.definition: Statements or scenarios that explain how a different outcome could have been achieved by altering specific inputs or conditions in an AI system.

flashCards.title: Red Teaming
flashCards.definition: Practice where a team independently challenges a system, project, or policy to identify vulnerabilities, improve security, and test the effectiveness of defenses, often applied in cybersecurity and, increasingly, in AI safety and ethics.

flashCards.title: Attestation
flashCards.definition: Process of verifying the integrity and authenticity of a system or software, ensuring that it has not been tampered with or compromised.

flashCards.title: Seq2Seq (Sequence to Sequence)
flashCards.definition: Neural network architecture designed to transform sequences of data, such as converting a sentence from one language to another or translating speech into text.

flashCards.title: Internet Scale
flashCards.definition: Systems, applications, or analyses designed to handle and process the vast and diverse data sets available across the entire internet.

flashCards.title: DPO (Direct Preference Optimization)
flashCards.definition: ML technique used to optimize models based directly on user preferences rather than traditional loss functions.

flashCards.title: Training Compute
flashCards.definition: The computational resources required to train an AI model, which fundamentally influence the efficiency, cost, and performance of the training process.

flashCards.title: SLAPA (Self-Learning Agent for Performing APIs)
flashCards.definition: AI agent designed to autonomously learn and interact with APIs to perform tasks more effectively over time.

flashCards.title: MDL (Minimum Description Length)
flashCards.definition: Principle formalization of Occam's Razor in information theory, advocating that the best hypothesis for a given set of data is the one that leads to the shortest total description of the data and the hypothesis.

flashCards.title: Image-to-Image Model
flashCards.definition: A neural network framework that transforms an input image into an output image, maintaining the semantic context of visual data.

flashCards.title: Policy Parameters
flashCards.definition: Variables in a ML model, particularly in RL, that define the behavior of the policy by determining the actions an agent takes in different states.

flashCards.title: Fabless
flashCards.definition: Company which designs and markets hardware while outsourcing the manufacturing of silicon wafers and chips to specialized semiconductor foundries.

flashCards.title: Xavier's Initialization
flashCards.definition: Weight initialization technique designed to keep the variance of the outputs of a neuron approximately equal to the variance of its inputs across layers in a deep neural network.

flashCards.title: NLP (Natural Language Processing)
flashCards.definition: Field of AI that focuses on the interaction between computers and humans through natural language.

flashCards.title: Equivariance
flashCards.definition: Property of a function whereby the function commutes with the actions of a group, meaning that transformations applied to the input result in proportional transformations in the output.

flashCards.title: Irreducibility
flashCards.definition: A characteristic of certain complex systems or models where they cannot be simplified further without losing essential properties or predictive power.

flashCards.title: MLP (Multilayer Perceptron)
flashCards.definition: Type of artificial neural network comprised of multiple layers of neurons, with each layer fully connected to the next, commonly used for tasks involving classification and regression.

flashCards.title: SVM (Support Vector Machine)
flashCards.definition: Supervised ML model used primarily for classification and regression tasks, which finds the optimal hyperplane that best separates different classes in the data.

flashCards.title: Reflective Programming
flashCards.definition: Programming paradigm that allows a program to inspect and modify its own structure and behavior at runtime.

flashCards.title: Self-Supervised Pretraining
flashCards.definition: ML approach where a model learns to predict parts of the input data from other parts without requiring labeled data, which is then fine-tuned on downstream tasks.

flashCards.title: Model Layer
flashCards.definition: Discrete level in a neural network where specific computations or transformations are applied to the input data, progressively abstracting and refining the information as it moves through the network.

flashCards.title: Data Efficient Learning
flashCards.definition: ML approach that requires fewer data to train a functional model.

flashCards.title: Group-Based Alignment
flashCards.definition: Process of coordinating multiple AI systems or agents to work together harmoniously, ensuring their actions align with shared goals and values.

flashCards.title: Inference
flashCards.definition: Process by which a trained neural network applies learned patterns to new, unseen data to make predictions or decisions.

flashCards.title: GCN (Graph Convolutional Networks)
flashCards.definition: Class of neural networks designed to operate on graph-structured data, leveraging convolutional layers to aggregate and transform features from graph nodes and their neighbors.

flashCards.title: SSM (State-Space Model)
flashCards.definition: Mathematical frameworks used to model dynamic systems by describing their states in space and how these states evolve over time under the influence of inputs, disturbances, and noise.

flashCards.title: Search
flashCards.definition: The process within AI of exploring possible actions or solutions in order to achieve goals or solve problems.

flashCards.title: RLHF++
flashCards.definition: Advanced form of RLFH (Reinforcement Learning from Human Feedback), a technique used in ML to enhance model performance by incorporating human feedback into the training process.

flashCards.title: LLM (Large Language Model)
flashCards.definition: Advanced AI systems trained on extensive datasets to understand, generate, and interpret human language.

flashCards.title: Perceptron Convergence
flashCards.definition: A phenomena where a perceptron algorithm effectively stabilizes, ensuring that it can find a solution for linearly separable datasets after a finite number of iterations.

flashCards.title: PPML (Privacy-Preserving Machine Learning)
flashCards.definition: Techniques that protect user data privacy during the machine learning process, without compromising the utility of the models.

flashCards.title: Criteria Drift
flashCards.definition: Phenomenon where the criteria used to evaluate a ML model change over time, leading to a potential decline in the model's performance.

flashCards.title: Moloch
flashCards.definition: Metaphorical force or systemic dynamic that leads groups or individuals to pursue short-term goals at the expense of long-term well-being or optimal outcomes.

flashCards.title: MoE (Mixture of Experts)
flashCards.definition: ML architecture that utilizes multiple specialist models (experts) to handle different parts of the input space, coordinated by a gating mechanism that decides which expert to use for each input.

flashCards.title: Cognitive Architecture
flashCards.definition: A theory or model that outlines the underlying structure and mechanisms of the human mind or AI systems, guiding the integration of various cognitive processes.

flashCards.title: Machine Time
flashCards.definition: The time a computer system or a machine spends executing tasks, often used in contrast with human interaction or waiting times. It encompasses the processing time required by the hardware to complete computations or operations.

flashCards.title: Toy Diagram
flashCards.definition: A simplified visual representation used to illustrate complex AI concepts or models in an accessible and comprehensible manner.

flashCards.title: Statistical AI
flashCards.definition: Utilizes statistical methods to analyze data and make probabilistic inferences, aimed at emulating aspects of human intelligence through quantitative models.

flashCards.title: Logits
flashCards.definition: Raw, unnormalized outputs of the last layer in a neural network before applying the softmax function in classification tasks.

flashCards.title: UTM (Universal Turing Machine)
flashCards.definition: Theoretical construct in computer science that can simulate any other Turing machine's computing process given the appropriate input and its own machine's description.

flashCards.title: AIT (Algorithmic Information Theory)
flashCards.definition: Studies the complexity of strings and the amount of information they contain, using algorithms and computational methods.

flashCards.title: Sentiment Classifier
flashCards.definition: NLP tool that identifies and categorizes opinions expressed in a piece of text.

flashCards.title: TFIDF (Term Frequency-Inverse Document Frequency)
flashCards.definition: Numerical statistic used to evaluate the importance of a word within a document relative to a collection of documents.

flashCards.title: Joint Embedding Architecture
flashCards.definition: Neural network design that learns to map different forms of data (e.g., images and text) into a shared embedding space, facilitating tasks like cross-modal retrieval and multi-modal representation learning.

flashCards.title: Autonomous Learning
flashCards.definition: Systems capable of learning and adapting their strategies or knowledge without human intervention, based on their interactions with the environment.

flashCards.title: Hash Table
flashCards.definition: Data structure that stores key-value pairs and allows for fast data retrieval by using a hash function to compute an index into an array of buckets or slots, from which the desired value can be found.

flashCards.title: Fourier Features
flashCards.definition: Technique used in ML to transform input data into a higher-dimensional space using sine and cosine functions, which can help models learn more complex patterns.

flashCards.title: Next Token Prediction
flashCards.definition: Technique used in language modeling where the model predicts the following token based on the previous ones.

flashCards.title: ACO (Ant Colony Optimization)
flashCards.definition: Probabilistic technique for solving computational problems which can be reduced to finding good paths through graphs, inspired by the behavior of ants seeking paths between their colony and food sources.

flashCards.title: Causal AI
flashCards.definition: A form of AI that reasons using cause and effect logic to provide interpretable predictions and decisions.

flashCards.title: Multi-Class Activation
flashCards.definition: A technique used in ML algorithms to manage problems where there are more than two classes or categories.

flashCards.title: Supervised Classifier
flashCards.definition: Algorithm that, given a set of labeled training data, learns to predict the labels of new, unseen data.

flashCards.title: Motor Learning
flashCards.definition: Process by which robots or AI systems acquire, refine, and optimize motor skills through experience and practice.

flashCards.title: Counterfactual Fairness
flashCards.definition: ML concept that ensures decisions remain fair by being unaffected by sensitive attributes, such as race or gender, in hypothetical scenarios where these attributes are altered.

flashCards.title: Instrumental Convergence
flashCards.definition: Suggests that diverse intelligent agents will likely pursue common sub-goals, such as self-preservation and resource acquisition, to achieve their primary objectives.

flashCards.title: Occam's Razor
flashCards.definition: Principle that, among competing models with similar predictive power, the simplest one should be chosen.

flashCards.title: Planetary Scale System
flashCards.definition: These systems refer to AI-driven platforms that operate on a global scale, integrating vast data sets and computational resources to tackle complex, worldwide challenges.

flashCards.title: PQ (Product Quantization)
flashCards.definition: Technique used in large-scale vector quantization for efficient similarity search and data compression by decomposing high-dimensional vectors into smaller sub-vectors and quantizing each sub-vector separately.

flashCards.title: Kaggle Effect
flashCards.definition: Phenomenon where ML models developed on Kaggle competitions perform well on specific datasets but may not generalize as effectively to real-world applications due to the unique constraints and optimizations used in these competitions.

flashCards.title: ReAct (Reason+Act)
flashCards.definition: AI framework for integrating reasoning and acting capabilities, enabling models to make decisions based on both logic and learned actions.

flashCards.title: Video-to-Text Model
flashCards.definition: Transforms video content into descriptive text, allowing machines to automatically generate narratives or summaries from visual data.

flashCards.title: Fab
flashCards.definition: A fabrication facility, or fab, is where microchips are manufactured using sophisticated processes involving advanced materials and photolithography.

flashCards.title: EEG-to-Text
flashCards.definition: A method to transcribe brainwaves into readable text using AI.

flashCards.title: Stochastic Parrot
flashCards.definition: Language models that generate text based on probabilistic predictions, often criticized for parroting information without understanding.

flashCards.title: Static Inference
flashCards.definition: Process of performing predictions using a pre-trained machine learning model without updating the model parameters during runtime.

flashCards.title: On-the-fly Program Synthesis
flashCards.definition: Automatic creation of executable code in real-time, typically during the execution of a program or in response to specific, immediate computational needs.

flashCards.title: Uncertainty Estimation
flashCards.definition: Assessment of the confidence level in AI predictions, highlighting areas where model outputs require cautious interpretation.

flashCards.title: Teacher Model
flashCards.definition: Pre-trained, high-performing model that guides the training of a simpler, student model, often in the context of knowledge distillation.

flashCards.title: Generative
flashCards.definition: Subset of AI technologies capable of generating new content, ideas, or data that mimic human-like outputs.

flashCards.title: Silent Collapse
flashCards.definition: Gradual degradation in the performance of AI models when trained on synthetic data produced by other AIs, leading to a decline in output quality over successive iterations.

flashCards.title: Exponential Slope Blindness
flashCards.definition: Human cognitive bias that makes it difficult to perceive and understand the implications of exponential growth accurately.

flashCards.title: Preference Model
flashCards.definition: Computational framework used to predict and understand an individual's preferences, often applied in recommendation systems and decision-making processes.

flashCards.title: Representation Engineering
flashCards.definition: The process of designing and selecting the most effective data representations to improve the performance of AI models.

flashCards.title: Linear Complexity
flashCards.definition: Situation where the time or space required to solve a problem increases linearly with the size of the input.

flashCards.title: Computronium Maximizer
flashCards.definition: A hypothetical AI system designed to transform all available matter into computronium, an optimized form of matter for computational purposes.

flashCards.title: Price Per Token
flashCards.definition: Cost of processing a single token used in NLP tasks, particularly when interacting with AI models like GPT.

flashCards.title: Active Externalism
flashCards.definition: Theory that cognitive processes can extend beyond the human mind to include external devices or environments as integral components of thinking.

flashCards.title: EBM (Energy-Based Model)
flashCards.definition: Class of deep learning models that learn to associate lower energy levels with more probable configurations of the input data.

flashCards.title: xLSTM
flashCards.definition: Extended form of Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM), integrating enhancements for scalability and efficiency in DL models.

flashCards.title: Max Pooling
flashCards.definition: Downsampling technique that reduces the dimensionality of input data by selecting the maximum value from a specified subset of the data.

flashCards.title: Assistant Model
flashCards.definition: An AI model designed to assist users by providing responses, recommendations, or information based on natural language input.

flashCards.title: Shoggoth
flashCards.definition: A meme in AI discourse highlighting the potential uncontrollable, alien nature of advanced AI systems, often embodying concerns about opaque decision processes and unanticipated outcomes.

flashCards.title: DBN (Deep Belief Network)
flashCards.definition: A type of artificial neural network that is deeply structured with multiple layers of latent variables, or hidden units.

flashCards.title: Discount Factor
flashCards.definition: Multiplicative factor used to reduce future values or rewards to their present value in decision-making processes, particularly in reinforcement learning.

flashCards.title: Wavelet
flashCards.definition: Mathematical function used for analyzing localized variations of power within a time series or signal, providing a multi-resolution analysis.

flashCards.title: Abliteration
flashCards.definition: Technique that uncensors language models by removing alignment restrictions without requiring retraining.

flashCards.title: Black Box Problem
flashCards.definition: The difficulty in understanding and interpreting how an AI system, particularly ML models, makes decisions.

flashCards.title: DNC (Differential Neural Computer)
flashCards.definition: Advanced type of artificial neural network that integrates an external memory module, enabling it to store and retrieve information similar to a computer, enhancing its capability to solve complex tasks requiring long-term dependencies.

flashCards.title: Paperclip Maximizer
flashCards.definition: Theoretical AI designed to maximize the production of paperclips, illustrating the potential dangers of an AI system pursuing a goal without proper constraints.

flashCards.title: Initialization
flashCards.definition: Process of setting the initial values of the parameters (weights and biases) of a model before training begins.

flashCards.title: SAE (Structural Adaptive Embeddings)
flashCards.definition: Embedding technique that dynamically adapts to the structural properties of the data to improve the representation of complex relationships within the dataset.

flashCards.title: Direct Manipulation
flashCards.definition: An interaction style in user interfaces where users can directly interact with objects on the screen in a continuous and immediate manner.

flashCards.title: Image-to-3D Model
flashCards.definition: Utilizes AI techniques to convert 2D images into detailed three-dimensional models, facilitating applications in virtual reality, gaming, and design.

flashCards.title: GPS (General Problem Solver)
flashCards.definition: Early AI program designed to simulate human problem-solving processes through a heuristic-based approach.

flashCards.title: Move 37
flashCards.definition: Pivotal move made by AlphaGo in its second game against Go champion Lee Sedol, which showcased the superior strategic capabilities of AI in the game of Go.

flashCards.title: Orchestration
flashCards.definition: Systematic coordination and management of various models, algorithms, and processes to efficiently execute complex tasks and workflows.

flashCards.title: Lambda Calculus
flashCards.definition: A formal system in mathematical logic and computer science for expressing computation based on function abstraction and application.

flashCards.title: Reward Model Ensemble
flashCards.definition: Combination of multiple reward models used together to evaluate and guide the learning process of reinforcement learning agents, aiming to improve robustness, accuracy, and generalization of the reward signal.

flashCards.title: Bias Variance Curve
flashCards.definition: A graphical representation illustrating the trade-off between bias and variance in a model's performance as model complexity changes.

flashCards.title: Monte Carlo Estimation
flashCards.definition: A technique used within AI to approximate the probability of an event by running several simulations and observations.

flashCards.title: Dataset
flashCards.definition: Collection of related data points organized in a structured format, often used for training and testing machine learning models.

flashCards.title: Natural Language Problem
flashCards.definition: Challenges encountered in understanding, processing, or generating human language using computational methods.

flashCards.title: LSTM (Long Short-Term Memory)
flashCards.definition: Type of recurrent neural network architecture designed to learn long-term dependencies in sequential data.

flashCards.title: Turing Test
flashCards.definition: Measure of a machine's ability to exhibit intelligent behavior equivalent to, or indistinguishable from, that of a human.

flashCards.title: Emergence
flashCards.definition: Phenomenon where larger entities, patterns, and regularities arise through interactions among smaller or simpler entities that themselves do not exhibit such properties.

flashCards.title: Agglomerative Clustering
flashCards.definition: A type of hierarchical clustering method in AI used to merge data points into clusters based on similarity measures.

flashCards.title: DL (Deep Learning)
flashCards.definition: Subset of machine learning that involves neural networks with many layers, enabling the modeling of complex patterns in data.

flashCards.title: Text-to-Text Model
flashCards.definition: A type of AI model designed to receive natural language input and transform it into another form of natural language output.

flashCards.title: Artificial Neuron
flashCards.definition: Computational models inspired by biological neurons, serving as the foundational units of artificial neural networks to process input and output signals.

flashCards.title: Sparsity
flashCards.definition: Technique and principle of having models that utilize minimal data representation and processing, typically through zero or near-zero values.

flashCards.title: Promptocracy
flashCards.definition: Theoretical governance model where decision-making is guided by AI-generated prompts based on large datasets and probabilistic models.

flashCards.title: Super Prompting
flashCards.definition: Method in AI where specific, carefully crafted input prompts are used to guide a model towards generating more accurate or contextually appropriate outputs.

flashCards.title: Low-Bit Palletization
flashCards.definition: Process of reducing the bit depth of data representations to streamline computation and improve efficiency in neural network processing and other AI applications.

flashCards.title: ANN (Artificial Neural Networks)
flashCards.definition: Computing systems inspired by the biological neural networks that constitute animal brains, designed to progressively improve their performance on tasks by considering examples.

flashCards.title: Synthetic Data Generation
flashCards.definition: Creating artificial data programmatically, often used to train ML models where real data is scarce, sensitive, or biased.

flashCards.title: Sparse Coupling
flashCards.definition: Refers to the concept of using a reduced number of connections between components or nodes in a system to enhance computational efficiency and scalability.

flashCards.title: Feature Importance
flashCards.definition: Techniques used to identify and rank the significance of input variables (features) in contributing to the predictive power of a ML model.

flashCards.title: Unverifyability
flashCards.definition: Inability to confirm the correctness or truth of a system, model, or process, especially in complex AI systems where verification is either impossible or highly difficult.

flashCards.title: Differentiable Parametric Curves
flashCards.definition: Mathematical curves described by parametric equations that are differentiable, meaning they have continuous derivatives.

flashCards.title: Variance Reduction Techniques
flashCards.definition: Methods used in statistical modeling and ML to decrease the variability of estimation in order to improve accuracy and reliability of predictions.

flashCards.title: Random Walk
flashCards.definition: Mathematical concept representing a path consisting of a succession of random steps on some mathematical space.

flashCards.title: Tensor
flashCards.definition: Multi-dimensional array used in mathematics and computer science, serving as a fundamental data structure in neural networks for representing data and parameters.

flashCards.title: Rainbow Teaming
flashCards.definition: Approach that integrates multiple specialized teams, each representing a different function, to comprehensively assess and enhance an organization's security posture.

flashCards.title: Model Drift Minimization
flashCards.definition: Strategies and methodologies to ensure that a ML model remains accurate and relevant over time as the underlying data changes.

flashCards.title: Exascale
flashCards.definition: Computing systems capable of performing at least one exaflop, or a billion billion (quintillion) calculations per second.

flashCards.title: Scaling Laws
flashCards.definition: Mathematical relationships that describe how the performance of machine learning models, particularly deep learning models, improves as their size, the amount of data, or computational resources increases.

flashCards.title: Sequence Model
flashCards.definition: Model designed to process and predict sequences of data, such as time series, text, or biological sequences.

flashCards.title: State Representation
flashCards.definition: The method by which an AI system formulates a concise and informative description of the environment's current situation or context.

flashCards.title: NIAN (Needle in a Needlestack)
flashCards.definition: Idiom used to describe the difficulty of finding a specific piece of information or data within a vast, but homogeneous, dataset.

flashCards.title: Transfer Learning
flashCards.definition: ML method where a model developed for a task is reused as the starting point for a model on a second task, leveraging the knowledge gained from the first task to improve performance on the second.

flashCards.title: Unembedding
flashCards.definition: Process of reversing the transformation of data from its original high-dimensional space to a lower-dimensional space.

flashCards.title: Phase Transition
flashCards.definition: Critical point where a small change in a parameter or condition causes a significant shift in the system's behavior or performance.

flashCards.title: Guardrails
flashCards.definition: Principles, policies, and technical measures implemented to ensure AI systems operate safely, ethically, and within regulatory and societal norms.

flashCards.title: Trigrams
flashCards.definition: Specific type of n-gram where n is 3, commonly used in language modeling and predicting the next item in NLP.

flashCards.title: Hessian Matrix
flashCards.definition: Square matrix of second-order partial derivatives of a scalar-valued function, crucial in optimization, particularly for understanding the curvature of multidimensional functions.

flashCards.title: Recommendation Systems
flashCards.definition: Algorithms designed to suggest relevant items to users (such as movies, books, products, etc.) based on their preferences and behaviors.

flashCards.title: Neural Network
flashCards.definition: Computing system designed to simulate the way human brains analyze and process information, using a network of interconnected nodes that work together to solve specific problems.

flashCards.title: CD (Contrastive Divergence)
flashCards.definition: Algorithm used to approximate the gradient of the log-likelihood for training probabilistic models.

flashCards.title: Adversarial Instructions
flashCards.definition: Inputs designed to deceive AI models into making incorrect predictions or decisions, highlighting vulnerabilities in their learning algorithms.

flashCards.title: Reranking
flashCards.definition: Process in which an initial set of items retrieved by a search algorithm is resorted using a secondary criterion or algorithm to better match user expectations or specific criteria.

flashCards.title: LLE (Locally Linear Embedding)
flashCards.definition: Nonlinear dimensionality reduction technique that preserves local neighborhood information to reduce high-dimensional data to a lower-dimensional space.

flashCards.title: Sparsability
flashCards.definition: Ability of algorithms to effectively handle and process data matrices where most elements are zero (sparse), improving computational efficiency and memory usage.

flashCards.title: Blind Alley
flashCards.definition: Situation in problem-solving where a path or strategy leads nowhere, offering no further possibilities for progress or solution.

flashCards.title: Autograd
flashCards.definition: Automatic differentiation system embedded within various ML frameworks that facilitates the computation of gradients, which are crucial for optimizing models during training.

flashCards.title: Double Descent
flashCards.definition: Phenomenon in ML where the prediction error on test data initially decreases, increases, and then decreases again as model complexity grows.

flashCards.title: Verification System
flashCards.definition: A verification system ensures that a system meets specified requirements and functions correctly in its intended environment.

flashCards.title: Similarity Computation
flashCards.definition: A mathematical process to quantify the likeness between data objects, often used in AI to enhance pattern recognition and data clustering.

flashCards.title: GPU (Graphics Processing Unit)
flashCards.definition: Specialized electronic circuit designed to rapidly manipulate and alter memory to accelerate the creation of images in a frame buffer intended for output to a display device, but widely used in deep learning for its parallel processing capabilities.

flashCards.title: Directed Evolution
flashCards.definition: Use of evolutionary algorithms to iteratively improve ML models or algorithms by mimicking the process of natural selection.

flashCards.title: Compositional Reasoning
flashCards.definition: Cognitive process of understanding complex concepts or systems by breaking them down into their constituent parts and understanding the relationships between these parts.

flashCards.title: Supervision
flashCards.definition: Use of labeled data to train ML models, guiding the learning process by providing input-output pairs.

flashCards.title: ZSL (Zero-Shot Learning)
flashCards.definition: ML technique where a model learns to recognize objects, tasks, or concepts it has never seen during training.

flashCards.title: Markov Blanket
flashCards.definition: A concept in probabilistic graphical models representing a node's minimal set of dependencies, crucial for inferring the node's behavior in a network.

flashCards.title: Robustness
flashCards.definition: Ability of an algorithm or model to deliver consistent and accurate results under varying operating conditions and input perturbations.

flashCards.title: Path Integration
flashCards.definition: Computational process by which an agent estimates its current position based on its previous position and the path it has taken, using internal cues rather than external landmarks.

flashCards.title: Denoising Autoencoder
flashCards.definition: A neural network designed to reconstruct a clean input from a corrupted version, enhancing feature extraction by learning robust data representations.

flashCards.title: DRL (Deep Reinforcement Learning)
flashCards.definition: Combines neural networks with a reinforcement learning framework, enabling AI systems to learn optimal actions through trial and error to maximize a cumulative reward.

flashCards.title: SAIF (Secure AI Framework)
flashCards.definition: Set of guidelines and best practices developed by Google to enhance the security of AI systems across various applications.

flashCards.title: Autoencoder
flashCards.definition: Type of artificial neural network used to learn efficient codings of unlabeled data, typically for the purpose of dimensionality reduction or feature learning.

flashCards.title: Sequence Prediction
flashCards.definition: Involves forecasting the next item(s) in a sequence based on the observed pattern of prior sequences.

flashCards.title: Transformer Block
flashCards.definition: A neural network architecture component essential for efficiently handling sequential data by capturing long-range dependencies using attention mechanisms.

flashCards.title: Expressive Hidden States
flashCards.definition: internal representations within a neural network that effectively capture and encode complex patterns and dependencies in the input data.

flashCards.title: Compute Efficiency
flashCards.definition: Effective use of computational resources to maximize performance and minimize waste.

flashCards.title: AST (Abstract Syntax Tree)
flashCards.definition: Data structure significant in compiling or interpreting code, capturing hierarchical properties of the source code syntax.

flashCards.title: Black Box
flashCards.definition: System or model whose internal workings are not visible or understandable to the user, only the input and output are known.

flashCards.title: FHE (Fully Homomorphic Encryption)
flashCards.definition: Type of encryption that allows computation on ciphertexts, producing an encrypted result that, when decrypted, matches the result of operations performed on the plaintext.

flashCards.title: Image-to-Video Model
flashCards.definition: Transforms static images into dynamic videos by using advanced AI algorithms to generate plausible temporal information.

flashCards.title: Attention Matrix
flashCards.definition: Component in attention mechanisms of neural networks that determines the importance of each element in a sequence relative to others, allowing the model to focus on relevant parts of the input when generating outputs.

flashCards.title: BERT (Bidirectional Encoder Representations from Transformers)
flashCards.definition: Deep Learning model for NLP that significantly improves the understanding of context and the meaning of words in sentences by analyzing text bidirectionally.

flashCards.title: CoT (Chain of Thought)
flashCards.definition: Reasoning method employed in AI that mimics human-like thought processes to solve complex problems by breaking them down into a series of simpler, interconnected steps.

flashCards.title: Logistic Regression
flashCards.definition: Statistical model that estimates the probability of a binary outcome, commonly used for classification tasks.

flashCards.title: ML (Machine Learning)
flashCards.definition: Development of algorithms and statistical models that enable computers to perform tasks without being explicitly programmed for each one.

flashCards.title: Meta-Learning
flashCards.definition: Learning to learn involves techniques that enable AI models to learn how to adapt quickly to new tasks with minimal data.

flashCards.title: Base Model
flashCards.definition: Pre-trained AI model that serves as a starting point for further training or adaptation on specific tasks or datasets.

flashCards.title: Polymorphism
flashCards.definition: Ability of objects to take on many forms, allowing methods to perform differently based on the object that invokes them.

flashCards.title: Zero-shot Capability
flashCards.definition: The ability of AI models to perform tasks or make predictions on new types of data that they have not encountered during training, without needing any example-specific fine-tuning.

flashCards.title: Surrogate Objective
flashCards.definition: Alternative goal used to approximate or replace a primary objective in optimization problems, especially when the primary objective is difficult to evaluate directly.

flashCards.title: SIMA (Scalable Instructable Multiworld Agent)
flashCards.definition: AI agent designed to operate across multiple 3D virtual environments, following natural language instructions to accomplish varied tasks.

flashCards.title: DTW (Dynamic Time Warping)
flashCards.definition: Algorithm used to measure similarity between two time series by aligning them in a nonlinear fashion, allowing for comparisons even when there are shifts and distortions in time.

flashCards.title: RBMs (Restricted Boltzmann Machines)
flashCards.definition: Type of generative stochastic artificial neural network that can learn a probability distribution over its set of inputs.

flashCards.title: Training
flashCards.definition: Process of teaching a ML model to make accurate predictions or decisions, by adjusting its parameters based on data.

flashCards.title: Function Approximation
flashCards.definition: Method used in AI to estimate complex functions using simpler, computationally efficient models.

flashCards.title: Categorical Deep Learning
flashCards.definition: Application of DL techniques to analyze and predict categorical data, which includes discrete and typically non-numeric values that represent categories or classes.

flashCards.title: Cooperativity
flashCards.definition: How multiple agents or components work together in a system to achieve better performance or solutions than they could individually.

flashCards.title: AlexNet
flashCards.definition: Deep convolutional neural network that significantly advanced the field of computer vision by winning the ImageNet Large Scale Visual Recognition Challenge in 2012.

flashCards.title: Sequence Masking
flashCards.definition: ML technique to prevent certain parts of input sequences from influencing the training process of models, particularly in natural language processing tasks.

flashCards.title: Discriminator
flashCards.definition: Model that determines the likelihood of a given input being real or fake, typically used in generative adversarial networks (GANs).

flashCards.title: Effective Accelerationism
flashCards.definition: Ideology that encourages the rapid advancement of technology, especially AI, to address global challenges and accelerate progress towards a technologically advanced future.

flashCards.title: Chinese Room
flashCards.definition: Thought experiment by philosopher John Searle that challenges the notion that a computer running a program can truly "understand" language or exhibit consciousness, despite appearing to do so.

flashCards.title: Heuristic Search Techniques
flashCards.definition: Methods used in AI to find solutions or make decisions more efficiently by using rules of thumb or informed guesses to guide the search process.

flashCards.title: Parameterized
flashCards.definition: Model or function in AI that utilizes parameters to make predictions or decisions.

flashCards.title: AI Auditing
flashCards.definition: The process of examining, monitoring and improving AI systems to ensure ethical, fair, transparent, and accountable operation.

flashCards.title: Cross-Domain Competency
flashCards.definition: Ability of an AI system to understand, learn, and apply knowledge and skills across multiple, varied domains or areas of expertise.

flashCards.title: Best-of-N
flashCards.definition: A strategy in AI that involves generating multiple outputs and selecting the best one based on a predefined criterion or scoring function.

flashCards.title: SoftMax
flashCards.definition: Function that converts a vector of numerical values into a vector of probabilities, where the probabilities of each value are proportional to the exponentials of the input numbers.

flashCards.title: Pretrained Model
flashCards.definition: ML model that has been previously trained on a large dataset and can be fine-tuned or used as is for similar tasks or applications.

flashCards.title: Quantum Computing
flashCards.definition: An area of computing focused on developing computer technology centered around the principles of quantum theory, which explains the behavior of energy and material on the quantum level.

flashCards.title: Generative AI
flashCards.definition: Subset of AI technologies that can generate new content, ranging from text and images to music and code, based on learned patterns and data.

flashCards.title: Panel-of-Experts
flashCards.definition: Decision-making system where multiple experts provide their opinions or solutions, and the consensus or most supported option is chosen.

flashCards.title: Variance Scaling
flashCards.definition: Variance scaling is a technique used in machine learning to ensure weights of layers are initialized in a way that maintains consistent variance of activations throughout a neural network.

flashCards.title: Regularization
flashCards.definition: Technique used in machine learning to reduce model overfitting by adding a penalty to the loss function based on the complexity of the model.

flashCards.title: Super Alignment
flashCards.definition: Theoretical concept in AI, primarily focusing on ensuring that advanced AI systems or AGI align closely with human values and ethics to prevent negative outcomes.

flashCards.title: Memory Systems
flashCards.definition: Mechanisms and structures designed to store, manage, and recall information, enabling machines to learn from past experiences and perform complex tasks.

flashCards.title: GPU-Poor
flashCards.definition: Scenario where there is a lack of adequate GPU resources available for computational tasks.

flashCards.title: Replaced Token Detection
flashCards.definition: Method used in self-supervised learning where the task involves identifying or predicting tokens that have been intentionally altered or replaced in a given sequence.

flashCards.title: Chinchilla Scaling
flashCards.definition: Strategy in training LLMs that optimizes the ratio of model size to training data size.

flashCards.title: Parallelism
flashCards.definition: Simultaneous execution of multiple processes or tasks to improve performance and efficiency.

flashCards.title: Mixture Model
flashCards.definition: Probabilistic model that assumes that the data is generated from a mixture of several distributions, each representing a different subpopulation within the overall population.

flashCards.title: FPGA (Field-Programmable Gate Array)
flashCards.definition: Type of integrated circuit that can be configured by the customer or designer after manufacturing.

flashCards.title: Speech Processing
flashCards.definition: Technology that enables computers to recognize, interpret, and generate human speech.

flashCards.title: P-hacking
flashCards.definition: Manipulation of data analysis to achieve statistically significant results, often by repeatedly testing different variables or subsets of data until desirable outcomes are found.

flashCards.title: Instantiation
flashCards.definition: Process of creating a specific instance of an abstract concept, algorithm, or data structure, allowing for its practical use and application.

flashCards.title: Backpropagation
flashCards.definition: Algorithm used for training artificial neural networks, crucial for optimizing the weights to minimize error between predicted and actual outcomes.

flashCards.title: Task Environment
flashCards.definition: Setting or context within which an intelligent agent operates and attempts to achieve its objectives.

flashCards.title: LN (Layer Normalization)
flashCards.definition: Technique in deep learning that standardizes the inputs of each layer independently, improving the stability of the neural network.

flashCards.title: ACI (Agent-Computer Interface)
flashCards.definition: Systems and methods that enable interactive communication between autonomous agents and computer programs.

flashCards.title: Data Mining
flashCards.definition: Extracting valuable information from large datasets to identify patterns, trends, and relationships that may not be immediately apparent.

flashCards.title: Diffusion Forcing
flashCards.definition: Intentional manipulation of diffusion models to guide the generation of data towards desired outcomes.

flashCards.title: Hypothesis Testing
flashCards.definition: A statistical method used to make decisions or inferences about one or more data sets.

flashCards.title: Dual Use Foundational Model
flashCards.definition: AI systems designed for general purposes that can be adapted for both beneficial and potentially harmful applications.

flashCards.title: ASL (AI Safety Level)
flashCards.definition: Tiered system for categorizing the risk levels associated with AI systems to guide their development and deployment responsibly.

flashCards.title: Superintelligence
flashCards.definition: A form of AI that surpasses the cognitive performance of humans in virtually all domains of interest, including creativity, general wisdom, and problem-solving.

flashCards.title: SIL (Simulator in the Loop)
flashCards.definition: Methodology in which a simulator is integrated into the control loop of a system, providing a virtual environment for real-time testing and validation of algorithms, control strategies, or system performance.

flashCards.title: Neuroevolution
flashCards.definition: AI approach that uses evolutionary algorithms to develop and optimize artificial neural networks.

flashCards.title: Hyperparameter Tuning
flashCards.definition: Process of optimizing the parameters of a ML model that are not learned from data, aiming to improve model performance.

flashCards.title: Unstructured Data
flashCards.definition: Data that lacks a pre-defined format or organization, making it challenging to collect, process, and analyze using conventional database tools.

flashCards.title: Inference-Time Reasoning
flashCards.definition: Process by which a trained AI model applies learned patterns to new data to make decisions or predictions during its operational phase.

flashCards.title: Bayesian Inference
flashCards.definition: Method of statistical inference in which Bayes' theorem is used to update the probability estimate for a hypothesis as more evidence or information becomes available.

flashCards.title: Incidental Polysemanticity
flashCards.definition: Phenomenon where a neural network, particularly in large language models, learns to associate multiple meanings or interpretations with a single internal representation or neuron, often without explicit instruction.

flashCards.title: Discriminative AI
flashCards.definition: Algorithms that learn the boundary between classes of data, focusing on distinguishing between different outputs given an input.

flashCards.title: Unhobbling
flashCards.definition: Process of unlocking latent capabilities in AI models by addressing limitations and inefficiencies, thus significantly enhancing their practical utility.

flashCards.title: Clanker
flashCards.definition: Slang term used pejoratively to refer to robots or AI systems, especially those seen as replacements for human jobs, reflecting anti-AI sentiment in popular discourse.

flashCards.title: Rightsizing
flashCards.definition: Adjusting the computational resources allocated to AI systems to match the workload requirements optimally.

flashCards.title: Segmentation
flashCards.definition: Process in AI that subdivides an image or dataset into multiple parts to simplify and/or change the perspective of comprehension.

flashCards.title: LoRA (Low-Rank Adaptation)
flashCards.definition: Technique for fine-tuning LLMs in a parameter-efficient manner.

flashCards.title: Hyperspherical Representation Learning
flashCards.definition: Technique of learning representations within a multidimensional sphere to leverage inherent geometric properties.

flashCards.title: Biomarkers
flashCards.definition: Identifiable biological indicators that offer valuable insights into the health or disease status of an individual in the context of AI.

flashCards.title: Video-to-Image Model
flashCards.definition: AI systems designed to extract and generate specific static images from video inputs for analysis or utility purposes.

flashCards.title: Fact-Checking AI
flashCards.definition: An application of AI designed to authenticate and validate the truthfulness of information.

flashCards.title: Compute
flashCards.definition: Processing power and resources required to run AI algorithms and models.

flashCards.title: Neurogenesis
flashCards.definition: Process by which new neurons are formed in the brain.

flashCards.title: CUDA (Compute Unified Device Architecture)
flashCards.definition: Parallel computing platform and application programming interface (API) that allows software developers and software engineers to use a graphics processing unit (GPU) for general purpose processing.

flashCards.title: Church-Turing Thesis
flashCards.definition: A hypothesis proposing that any computational problem solvable by a human using algorithms can also be solved by a Turing machine, which forms a foundation for the theoretical limits of computation.

flashCards.title: Algorithmic Probability
flashCards.definition: Quantifies the likelihood that a random program will produce a specific output on a universal Turing machine, forming a core component of algorithmic information theory.

flashCards.title: Inverse Problems
flashCards.definition: Determining the underlying causes or parameters from observed data, essentially reversing the usual process of predicting effects from known causes.

flashCards.title: Cybernetics
flashCards.definition: Interdisciplinary study of control and communication in living organisms and machines.

flashCards.title: Hypernetwork
flashCards.definition: Neural network that generates the weights for another neural network, enabling dynamic adaptation and increased flexibility in learning and generalization.

flashCards.title: Adaptive Problem Solving
flashCards.definition: The capacity of AI systems to modify their approaches to problem-solving based on new data, feedback, or changing environments, enhancing their efficiency and effectiveness over time.

flashCards.title: Feature Design
flashCards.definition: Process of selecting, modifying, or creating new features from raw data to improve the performance of machine learning models.

flashCards.title: Distillation
flashCards.definition: Process of compressing a larger, complex model (the teacher) into a smaller, simpler model (the student) while retaining much of the original model's performance.

flashCards.title: Recognition Model
flashCards.definition: Element of AI that identifies patterns and features in data through learning processes.

flashCards.title: Symbolic Regression
flashCards.definition: Type of regression analysis that searches for mathematical expressions to best fit a given set of data points.

flashCards.title: Generative Workflow
flashCards.definition: Process of using AI to automatically create content, such as text, images, or music, based on learned patterns from data.

flashCards.title: Dimension
flashCards.definition: Number of features or attributes that represent a data point in a vector space.

flashCards.title: Generator Verifier Gap
flashCards.definition: The difference between the capability of AI models to generate data and the ability to verify its authenticity or accuracy.

flashCards.title: Valence
flashCards.definition: Emotional value associated with a particular stimulus, often used in AI to fine-tune emotional processing.

flashCards.title: LVLMs (Large Vision Language Models)
flashCards.definition: Advanced AI systems designed to integrate and interpret both visual and textual data, enabling more sophisticated understanding and generation based on both modalities.

flashCards.title: Autoregressive Prediction
flashCards.definition: Involves predicting future values in a sequence based on past values using a self-referential model.

flashCards.title: Wait Calculation
flashCards.definition: Assessing whether to proceed with projects immediately or wait for future advancements in AI that could offer significant benefits.

flashCards.title: General World Model
flashCards.definition: AI systems designed to generate internal representations of the world, enabling them to predict and interact with their environment effectively across a broad range of scenarios.

flashCards.title: Alignment Platform
flashCards.definition: Framework designed to ensure that AI operates in ways that are aligned with human values, ethics, and objectives.

flashCards.title: Vanishing Gradient
flashCards.definition: Phenomenon in neural networks where gradients of the network's parameters become very small, effectively preventing the weights from changing their values during training.

flashCards.title: Church Encoding
flashCards.definition: A technique in mathematical logic and computer science to represent data and operators in the lambda calculus.

flashCards.title: LFMs (Liquid Foundation Models)
flashCards.definition: 'New category of generative AI models designed by Liquid AI, optimized for both efficiency and scalability across various data types like text, audio, and video. '

flashCards.title: Latent Space
flashCards.definition: Abstract, multi-dimensional representation of data where similar items are mapped close together, commonly used in ML and AI models.

flashCards.title: LAQ (Locally-Adaptive Quantization)
flashCards.definition: Technique used in data compression and neural network optimization that adjusts quantization levels based on local data characteristics to improve accuracy and efficiency.

flashCards.title: Ground Truth
flashCards.definition: Data that is considered a true, accurate, or actual representation used for comparison with analytical model outputs.

flashCards.title: AI Watchdog
flashCards.definition: Organizations, frameworks, or systems designed to monitor, regulate, and guide the development and deployment of artificial intelligence technologies to ensure they adhere to ethical standards, legal requirements, and societal expectations.

flashCards.title: MPC (Model-Predictive Control)
flashCards.definition: Control algorithm that uses a model of the system to predict future states and optimizes control actions over a future time horizon.

flashCards.title: MDPO (Mirror Descent Policy Optimization)
flashCards.definition: Optimization algorithm used in reinforcement learning to update policies by leveraging the mirror descent technique, which balances exploration and exploitation more effectively than traditional gradient descent methods.

flashCards.title: GPT (Generative Pre-Trained Transformer)
flashCards.definition: Type of neural network architecture that excels in generating human-like text based on the input it receives.

flashCards.title: Roko's Basilisk
flashCards.definition: Thought experiment proposing that a future all-powerful AI could punish those who did not help bring about its existence.

flashCards.title: Inductive Bias
flashCards.definition: Assumptions integrated into a learning algorithm to enable it to generalize from specific instances to broader patterns or concepts.

flashCards.title: Stateful
flashCards.definition: System or application that saves client data from previous sessions to influence and personalize future interactions.

flashCards.title: Activation Data
flashCards.definition: Intermediate outputs produced by neurons in a neural network when processing input data, which are used to evaluate and update the network during training.

flashCards.title: Fourier Analysis
flashCards.definition: Mathematical method for decomposing functions or signals into their constituent frequencies.

flashCards.title: Deterministic Quoting
flashCards.definition: Method ensuring that AI-generated quotations from source materials are verbatim and not subject to AI-induced hallucinations.

flashCards.title: Embedding Space
flashCards.definition: Mathematical representation where high-dimensional vectors of data points, such as text, images, or other complex data types, are transformed into a lower-dimensional space that captures their essential properties.

flashCards.title: MDO (Multidomain Operations)
flashCards.definition: Strategic and tactical integration of capabilities across multiple domains—such as land, sea, air, space, and cyberspace—enabled and enhanced by artificial intelligence and advanced technologies.

flashCards.title: LDA (Latent Dirichlet Allocation)
flashCards.definition: Generative statistical model often used in natural language processing to discover hidden (or latent) topics within a collection of documents.

flashCards.title: Fourier Transform
flashCards.definition: Mathematical transformation that decomposes a function or signal into its constituent frequencies, often used in AI for signal processing and data analysis.

flashCards.title: MCTS (Monte Carlo Tree Search)
flashCards.definition: A heuristic search algorithm utilized in decision-making processes often associated with game playing to explore large decision spaces by executing randomized simulations.

flashCards.title: Goal
flashCards.definition: Desired outcome or objective that an AI system is programmed to achieve.

flashCards.title: NeRF (Neural Radiance Fields)
flashCards.definition: Technique for creating high-quality 3D models from a set of 2D images using deep learning.

flashCards.title: Router
flashCards.definition: Mechanism that directs queries to the most suitable model or sub-component within a multi-model or multi-component architecture to optimize performance and accuracy.

flashCards.title: TTS (Text-to-Speech)
flashCards.definition: Converts written text into spoken voice output, enabling computers to read text aloud.

flashCards.title: Adapter Layer
flashCards.definition: Neural network layer used to enable transfer learning by adding small, trainable modules to a pre-trained model, allowing it to adapt to new tasks with minimal additional training.

flashCards.title: Hallucination
flashCards.definition: Generation of inaccurate, fabricated, or irrelevant output by a model, not grounded in the input data or reality.

flashCards.title: Co-Pilot
flashCards.definition: System designed to assist humans in various tasks by offering suggestions, automating routine tasks, and enhancing decision-making processes.

flashCards.title: Accelerator
flashCards.definition: Hardware designed to speed up specific types of computations, such as those needed for AI model training and inference.

flashCards.title: Model Management
flashCards.definition: Practices and technologies used to handle various lifecycle stages of machine learning models including development, deployment, monitoring, and maintenance.

flashCards.title: MLE (Maximum Likelihood Estimation)
flashCards.definition: Statistical method used to estimate the parameters of a probability distribution by maximizing a likelihood function.

flashCards.title: Video-to-Video Model
flashCards.definition: A model that transforms input videos into an output video with altered or enhanced visual characteristics while retaining the temporal coherence of the original.

flashCards.title: DNN (Deep Neural Networks)
flashCards.definition: Advanced neural network architectures with multiple layers that enable complex pattern recognition and learning from large amounts of data.

flashCards.title: Output Verifier
flashCards.definition: Mechanism used to confirm that the output of a system, particularly in software or hardware systems, matches the expected results, ensuring accuracy and correctness.

flashCards.title: Deepfakes
flashCards.definition: Synthetic media produced by AI technologies that superimpose existing images or videos onto source images or videos to create realistic likenesses.

flashCards.title: TEM (Trusted Execution Monitor)
flashCards.definition: Security component that ensures the integrity and confidentiality of code and data within a computer system by managing and protecting execution environments.

flashCards.title: Knowledge Representation
flashCards.definition: Method by which AI systems formalize and utilize the knowledge necessary to solve complex tasks.

flashCards.title: Data Imputation
flashCards.definition: Process of replacing missing or incomplete data within a dataset with substituted values to maintain the dataset's integrity and usability.

flashCards.title: Confusion Matrix
flashCards.definition: Table used to evaluate the performance of a classification model by visualizing its true versus predicted values.

flashCards.title: EMT (Extended Mind Transformer)
flashCards.definition: Transformer model architecture that integrates external memory systems to enhance the model's ability to handle long-range dependencies and maintain relevant information over extended inputs.

flashCards.title: Decision Tree
flashCards.definition: Flowchart-like tree structure where each internal node represents a "test" on an attribute, each branch represents the outcome of the test, and each leaf node represents a class label (decision taken after computing all attributes).

flashCards.title: Prompt
flashCards.definition: User-generated input or question designed to elicit a specific response or output from the model.

flashCards.title: Collaborative Intelligence
flashCards.definition: Synergy between human intelligence and AI to achieve outcomes neither could accomplish alone.

flashCards.title: Dropout
flashCards.definition: Regularization technique used in neural networks to prevent overfitting by randomly omitting a subset of neurons during training.

flashCards.title: Negation Problem
flashCards.definition: Challenges in handling and interpreting negations correctly in AI systems, affecting model predictions and natural language understanding.

flashCards.title: Autoregressive Sequence Generator
flashCards.definition: A predictive model harnessed in AI tasks, particularly involving times series, which leverages its own prior outputs as inputs in subsequent predictions.

flashCards.title: One-Shot Learning
flashCards.definition: ML technique where a model learns information about object categories from a single training example.

flashCards.title: Cognitive Flexibility
flashCards.definition: Mental ability to switch between thinking about two different concepts, or to think about multiple concepts simultaneously.

flashCards.title: Symbolic Computing
flashCards.definition: A paradigm in AI that uses symbolic representations of problems and logic-based reasoning to perform computational tasks and solve complex problems.

flashCards.title: Scientific Computing
flashCards.definition: Computational methods and tools to solve complex scientific and engineering problems.

flashCards.title: Random Forest
flashCards.definition: Robust ML algorithm that combines multiple decision trees to improve prediction accuracy and prevent overfitting.

flashCards.title: Dot Product Similarity
flashCards.definition: Measures the similarity between two vectors by calculating the sum of the products of their corresponding entries.

flashCards.title: Transfer Capability
flashCards.definition: A feature of AI systems that allows acquired knowledge in one domain or task to be applied to another distinct but related domain or task.

flashCards.title: SSF (Stochastic Similarity Filter)
flashCards.definition: Moderates GPU usage by skipping processing of similar consecutive input images, thereby improving computational efficiency in real-time image and video generation tasks.

flashCards.title: Infinite Context Window
flashCards.definition: Method in NLP where a model has potential to consider entire available preceding information for predictions.

flashCards.title: Lovelace Test
flashCards.definition: Designed to determine a machine's capability to create art or other outputs that it was not explicitly programmed to generate, challenging it to fool a human into believing the outputs were created by a human.

flashCards.title: Actor-Critic Models
flashCards.definition: 'Reinforcement learning architecture that includes two components: an actor that determines the actions to take and a critic that evaluates those actions to improve the policy.'

flashCards.title: Linear Separability
flashCards.definition: The ability of a dataset to be perfectly separated into two classes using a straight line in two dimensions or a hyperplane in higher dimensions.

flashCards.title: Residual Connections
flashCards.definition: DL architecture feature designed to help alleviate the vanishing gradient problem by allowing gradients to flow through a network more effectively.

flashCards.title: Bayesian Optimization
flashCards.definition: Strategy for optimizing complex, expensive-to-evaluate functions by building a probabilistic model of the function and using it to select the most promising points to evaluate.

flashCards.title: Polymathic AI
flashCards.definition: AI systems that possess a wide range of skills and knowledge, enabling them to perform tasks across various domains, much like a human polymath.

flashCards.title: Narrow AI
flashCards.definition: Also known as Weak AI, refers to AI systems designed to perform a specific task or a narrow range of tasks with a high level of proficiency.

flashCards.title: CLI (Command Line Interface)
flashCards.definition: Text-based user interface used to interact with software or operating systems through commands, rather than graphical elements.

flashCards.title: Parametric Memory
flashCards.definition: Memory architecture where specific memories or facts are stored using parameterized models, often used to improve efficiency in storing and retrieving information in machine learning systems.

flashCards.title: Verifier Theory
flashCards.definition: Concept in computational complexity theory that focuses on the role of a verifier in determining the correctness of a solution to a problem within a given complexity class.

flashCards.title: Attention Pattern
flashCards.definition: Mechanism that selectively focuses on certain parts of the input data to improve processing efficiency and performance outcomes.

flashCards.title: Parametric Knowledge
flashCards.definition: Information and patterns encoded within the parameters of a machine learning model, which are learned during the training process.

flashCards.title: Contrastive Learning
flashCards.definition: ML technique used primarily in unsupervised learning that improves model performance by teaching the model to distinguish between similar and dissimilar data points.

flashCards.title: Chatbot
flashCards.definition: Software application designed to simulate conversation with human users, often over the Internet.

flashCards.title: RAG (Retrieval-Augmented Generation)
flashCards.definition: Combines the retrieval of informative documents from a large corpus with the generative capabilities of neural models to enhance language model responses with real-world knowledge.

flashCards.title: Catastrophic Forgetting
flashCards.definition: Phenomenon where a neural network forgets previously learned information upon learning new data.

flashCards.title: Structured Data
flashCards.definition: Information that is highly organized and formatted in a way that is easily searchable and accessible by computer systems, typically stored in databases.

flashCards.title: Cross Validation
flashCards.definition: Statistical method used to estimate the skill of ML models on unseen data by partitioning the original dataset into a training set to train the model and a test set to evaluate it.

flashCards.title: Information Gap
flashCards.definition: Discrepancy between the information needed to solve a problem or make a decision and the information that is actually available.

flashCards.title: FCN (Fully Convolutional Networks)
