flashCards.definition: Neural network architecture designed specifically for image segmentation tasks, where the goal is to classify each pixel of an image into a category.

flashCards.title: Human-Level AI
flashCards.definition: AI systems that can perform any intellectual task with the same proficiency as a human being.

flashCards.title: Sequential Models
flashCards.definition: Type of data models in AI where the arrangement of data points or events adhere to a specific order for predictive analysis and pattern recognition.

flashCards.title: Explainability
flashCards.definition: Ability of a system to transparently convey how it arrived at a decision, making its operations understandable to humans.

flashCards.title: Automaton
flashCards.definition: A self-operating machine or control mechanism designed to follow a predetermined sequence of operations or respond to encoded instructions.

flashCards.title: Private Cloud Compute
flashCards.definition: Dedicated cloud infrastructure to provide cloud computing services exclusively to a single organization, ensuring enhanced control, privacy, and security.

flashCards.title: Probabilistic Inferencing
flashCards.definition: A technique in AI focused on drawing conclusions based on the probability of different outcomes, given partial or uncertain information.

flashCards.title: Open-Ended AI
flashCards.definition: AI systems designed to adapt and improve continuously, capable of generating creative or novel solutions without a predefined endpoint or specific task.

flashCards.title: Transposed Convolutional Layer
flashCards.definition: Type of neural network layer that performs the opposite operation of a traditional convolutional layer, effectively upscaling input feature maps to a larger spatial resolution.

flashCards.title: Triple
flashCards.definition: Data structure in the form of a three-part entity consisting of a subject, predicate, and object, commonly used in semantic web technologies and knowledge graphs.

flashCards.title: Salience
flashCards.definition: Quality by which certain aspects of a dataset or information stand out as particularly noticeable or important in a given context.

flashCards.title: RLHF (Reinforcement Learning from Human Feedback)
flashCards.definition: Technique that combines reinforcement learning (RL) with human feedback to guide the learning process towards desired outcomes.

flashCards.title: Policy Learning
flashCards.definition: Branch of reinforcement learning where the objective is to find an optimal policy that dictates the best action to take in various states to maximize cumulative reward.

flashCards.title: Early Exit Loss
flashCards.definition: An optimization technique in AI models that balances overall accuracy and computational efficiency.

flashCards.title: Interestingness
flashCards.definition: Measure of how engaging or surprising information is, often used in ML and computational creativity to prioritize novel and useful data.

flashCards.title: Information Integration
flashCards.definition: Process of combining data from different sources to provide a unified view.

flashCards.title: IRL (Inverse Reinforcement Learning)
flashCards.definition: Technique in which an algorithm learns the underlying reward function of an environment based on observed behavior from an agent, essentially inferring the goals an agent is trying to achieve.

flashCards.title: Matryoshka Embedding
flashCards.definition: Method of representing nested structures in data using embeddings that encapsulate multiple layers of information, similar to Russian Matryoshka nesting dolls.

flashCards.title: C2PA (Coalition for Content Provenance and Authenticity)
flashCards.definition: Initiative focused on establishing industry standards for authenticating digital media content to combat misinformation and ensure content provenance.

flashCards.title: Parameter
flashCards.definition: Variable that is internal to the model and whose value is estimated from the training data.

flashCards.title: Causal Transformer
flashCards.definition: A neural network model that utilizes causality to improve sequence prediction tasks.

flashCards.title: Distillation Method
flashCards.definition: A technique used to streamline complex AI models by transferring the knowledge of a large model into a smaller, more efficient model without significant loss in performance.

flashCards.title: Symbolic AI
flashCards.definition: Also known as Good Old-Fashioned AI (GOFAI), involves the manipulation of symbols to represent problems and compute solutions through rules.

flashCards.title: Attention Masking
flashCards.definition: Technique used in models based on transformers, where it manipulates the handling of sequence order and irrelevant elements in ML tasks.

flashCards.title: Nationalization
flashCards.definition: Government's takeover or control of AI technology and assets, typically to secure national interests, enhance regulatory oversight, or maintain sovereignty over critical technological infrastructure.

flashCards.title: Knowledge Graph
flashCards.definition: Organizes and represents data as an interconnected network of entities (such as objects, events, concepts) and their relationships.

flashCards.title: A-Life (Artificial Life)
flashCards.definition: Studies the simulation of life processes within computers or synthetic systems to gain insights into biological phenomena.

flashCards.title: Imitation Learning
flashCards.definition: AI technique where models learn to perform tasks by mimicking human behavior or strategies demonstrated in training data.

flashCards.title: HPOC (Human Point of Contact)
flashCards.definition: Designated person responsible for overseeing and managing interactions between an AI system and its users or other systems.

flashCards.title: Discontinuous Jump
flashCards.definition: Sudden, significant leap in the performance or capability of an AI system, deviating sharply from its previous trajectory of incremental improvements.

flashCards.title: Solution Space
flashCards.definition: Refers to the set of all possible solutions to a given problem or decision-making scenario.

flashCards.title: Autonomous Agents
flashCards.definition: Systems capable of independent action in dynamic, unpredictable environments to achieve designated objectives.

flashCards.title: Numerosity
flashCards.definition: Understanding of the quantitative attributes revolving around the number of elements in a data set.

flashCards.title: AGI (Artificial General Intelligence)
flashCards.definition: AI capable of understanding, learning, and applying knowledge across a wide range of tasks, matching or surpassing human intelligence.

flashCards.title: Streaming
flashCards.definition: Continuous generation and delivery of text in real-time as the model processes input sequentially.

flashCards.title: Neurosymbolic AI
flashCards.definition: Integration of neural networks with symbolic AI to create systems that can both understand and manipulate symbols in a manner similar to human cognitive processes.

flashCards.title: Confidential Computing
flashCards.definition: Security measure that protects data in use by performing computation in a hardware-based environment, preventing unauthorized access or visibility even if the system is compromised.

flashCards.title: In-Context Learning
flashCards.definition: Method where an AI model uses the context provided in a prompt to guide its responses without additional external training.

flashCards.title: Thought Token
flashCards.definition: Computational abstraction used in NLP models to represent and manipulate complex ideas or concepts within sequences of text.

flashCards.title: GQN (Generative Query Network)
flashCards.definition: Neural network architecture designed to enable machines to understand and generate visual scenes from different viewpoints based on limited observations.

flashCards.title: Socratic Model
flashCards.definition: Conversational AI that is designed to engage in dialogue in a manner akin to Socratic questioning, aiming to stimulate critical thinking and draw out ideas and underlying presuppositions.

flashCards.title: MCP neuron
flashCards.definition: Early computational model of a biological neuron forming the basis for artificial neural networks.

flashCards.title: Process Reward Model
flashCards.definition: A framework used to assess and guide AI systems by providing feedback mechanisms that evaluate and reinforce desired outcomes within a given process.

flashCards.title: AI Winter
flashCards.definition: Periods of reduced funding and interest in AI research and development, often due to unmet expectations and lack of significant progress.

flashCards.title: Markov Chain
flashCards.definition: Stochastic model describing a sequence of possible events in which the probability of each event depends only on the state attained in the previous event.

flashCards.title: Grounding
flashCards.definition: Process of linking abstract symbols or data representations to real-world meanings or experiences, enabling the system to understand and act based on those symbols in a meaningful way.

flashCards.title: Ensamble Algorithm
flashCards.definition: Combines multiple machine learning models to improve overall performance by reducing bias, variance, or noise.

flashCards.title: AutoML (Automated Machine Learning)
flashCards.definition: Streamlines the process of applying ML by automating the tasks of selecting the appropriate algorithms and tuning their hyperparameters.

flashCards.title: Teacher-Guided Rejection Sampling
flashCards.definition: Advanced ML technique that refines a model by iteratively sampling and accepting data based on evaluations from multiple expert models (teachers).

flashCards.title: Volumetric AI
flashCards.definition: AI techniques to process, analyze, and generate three-dimensional volumetric data, often used in fields like medical imaging, 3D reconstruction, and virtual reality.

flashCards.title: GAN (Generative Adversarial Network)
flashCards.definition: Class of AI algorithms used in unsupervised ML, implemented by a system of two neural networks contesting with each other in a game.

flashCards.title: Out of Distribution
flashCards.definition: Data that differs significantly from the training data used to train a machine learning model, leading to unreliable or inaccurate predictions.

flashCards.title: Autocomplete
flashCards.definition: Feature in software applications that predicts and suggests possible completions for a user’s input, such as text or code, based on partial input data.

flashCards.title: Stacking
flashCards.definition: ML ensemble technique that combines multiple classification or regression models via a meta-classifier or meta-regressor to improve prediction accuracy.

flashCards.title: QA (Question Answering)
flashCards.definition: Field of natural language processing focused on building systems that automatically answer questions posed by humans in a natural language.

flashCards.title: Hierarchy of Generalizations
flashCards.definition: Conceptual framework in ML that organizes features or representations from specific to general, often used in neural networks to capture varying levels of abstraction in data.

flashCards.title: Traceability
flashCards.definition: Ability to track and document the origins, evolution, and interactions of data, models, and decisions throughout the AI lifecycle.

flashCards.title: Unified Embedding
flashCards.definition: A technique that integrates multiple types of data into a single, cohesive representation to improve the performance of AI models in tasks such as multimodal learning, natural language processing, or cross-domain applications.

flashCards.title: Branching Factor
flashCards.definition: Number of possible actions or moves that can be taken from any given point in a decision-making process, such as in game trees or search algorithms.

flashCards.title: Context Window
flashCards.definition: Predefined span of text surrounding a specific word or phrase that algorithms analyze to determine its meaning, relevance, or relationship with other words.

flashCards.title: Constitutional AI
flashCards.definition: Development of foundational principles and regulations that govern the design, deployment, and operation of AI systems to ensure they adhere to ethical standards, human rights, and democratic values.

flashCards.title: TRPO (Trust Region Policy Optimization)
flashCards.definition: Advanced algorithm used in RL to ensure stable and reliable policy updates by optimizing within a trust region, thus preventing drastic policy changes.

flashCards.title: Hierarchical Planning
flashCards.definition: Approach to solving complex problems by breaking them down into more manageable sub-problems, organizing these into a hierarchy.

flashCards.title: Precomputed Policy
flashCards.definition: A strategy computed in advance for decision-making processes in AI systems, particularly within reinforcement learning, to optimize future actions.

flashCards.title: ASIC (Application-Specific Integrated Circuit)
flashCards.definition: A microchip designed for a specific application or function, particularly used in electronics where high efficiency and low power consumption are required.

flashCards.title: Bias-Variance Dilemma
flashCards.definition: Fundamental problem in supervised ML that involves a trade-off between a model’s ability to minimize error due to bias and error due to variance.

flashCards.title: Model Collapse
flashCards.definition: Phenomenon where a ML model, particularly in unsupervised or generative learning, repeatedly produces identical or highly similar outputs despite varying inputs, leading to a loss of diversity in the generated data.

flashCards.title: Benchmark
flashCards.definition: Standard or set of standards used to measure and compare the performance of algorithms, models, or systems.

flashCards.title: Token Processing
flashCards.definition: The breaking down of text into tokens, such as words or subwords, which are then used as elemental units for many NLP tasks.

flashCards.title: Vectorization
flashCards.definition: Process of converting non-numeric data into numeric format so that it can be used by ML algorithms.

flashCards.title: Subsymbolic AI
flashCards.definition: AI approaches that do not use explicit symbolic representation of knowledge but instead rely on distributed, often neural network-based methods to process and learn from data.

flashCards.title: ControlNet
flashCards.definition: Neural network architecture designed to add spatial conditioning controls to diffusion models, enabling precise manipulation without altering the original model's integrity.

flashCards.title: Parameter Size
flashCards.definition: Count of individual weights in a ML model that are learned from data during training.

flashCards.title: CLIP (Contrastive Language–Image Pre-training)
flashCards.definition: Machine learning model developed by OpenAI that learns visual concepts from natural language descriptions, enabling it to understand images in a manner aligned with textual descriptions.

flashCards.title: Toy Program
flashCards.definition: Simple, small-scale software application created primarily for educational purposes, testing, or proof of concept rather than for real-world use.

flashCards.title: Complex Interaction
flashCards.definition: Intricate, multi-layered exchanges or behaviors between components of an AI system, or between the AI system and its environment, which may involve non-linear dynamics and feedback loops.

flashCards.title: VQA (Visual Question Answering)
flashCards.definition: Field of AI where systems are designed to answer questions about visual content, such as images or videos.

flashCards.title: Instruction-Following
flashCards.definition: Ability to accurately understand and execute tasks based on given directives.

flashCards.title: Negative Feedback
flashCards.definition: Control mechanism where the output of a system is fed back into the system in a way that counteracts fluctuations from a setpoint, thereby promoting stability.

flashCards.title: Meta Prompt
flashCards.definition: AI technique that emphasizes the structural and syntactical framework of prompts to guide models in problem-solving and task execution, prioritizing the 'how' of information presentation over the 'what'.

flashCards.title: Vector Database
flashCards.definition: Specialized database optimized for storing and querying vectors, which are arrays of numbers representing data in high-dimensional space.

flashCards.title: JEST (Multimodal Contrastive Learning with Joint Example Selection)
flashCards.definition: AI technique that enhances the learning of shared representations across different modalities by jointly selecting and leveraging relevant examples.

flashCards.title: A-B Testing
flashCards.definition: Method used to compare two versions of a variable to determine which one performs better in achieving a specific outcome.

flashCards.title: Jagged Frontier
flashCards.definition: Metaphorically describes an area of AI research characterized by rapid, uneven advances and significant uncertainties or complexities.

flashCards.title: Overhang
flashCards.definition: Disparity between the minimum computation needed for a certain performance level and the actual computation used in training a model, often leading to superior model performance.

flashCards.title: Inductive Prior
flashCards.definition: Set of assumptions or biases that a ML model uses to infer patterns from data and make predictions, effectively guiding the learning process based on prior knowledge or expected behavior.

flashCards.title: HPC (High Performance Compute)
flashCards.definition: A practice of aggregating computing power in a way that delivers significantly higher performance than an average desktop or workstation.

flashCards.title: Object Detection
flashCards.definition: Computer vision technique that identifies and locates objects within an image or video frame.

flashCards.title: Clustering
flashCards.definition: Unsupervised learning method used to group a set of objects in such a way that objects in the same group (called a cluster) are more similar to each other than to those in other groups.

flashCards.title: GLU (Gated Linear Unit)
flashCards.definition: Neural network component that uses a gating mechanism to control information flow, improving model efficiency and performance.

flashCards.title: Token
flashCards.definition: Basic unit of data processed in NLP tasks, representing words, characters, or subwords.

flashCards.title: Prompt Chaining
flashCards.definition: Technique in AI and ML where multiple prompts or tasks are sequentially connected, allowing the output of one step to become the input for the next, effectively enabling more complex and nuanced operations.

flashCards.title: Regime
flashCards.definition: Distinct operational or behavioral mode in which an AI system functions, characterized by specific patterns or properties of data, parameters, or algorithms.

flashCards.title: Convolution
flashCards.definition: Mathematical operation used in signal processing and image processing to combine two functions, resulting in a third function that represents how one function modifies the other.

flashCards.title: Convergence
flashCards.definition: The point at which an algorithm or learning process stabilizes, reaching a state where further iterations or data input do not significantly alter its outcome.

flashCards.title: TPU (Tensor Processing Units)
flashCards.definition: Specialized hardware accelerators designed to significantly speed up the calculations required for ML tasks.

flashCards.title: Composability
flashCards.definition: Design feature in software systems that allows different components to be selected and assembled in various combinations to satisfy specific user requirements.

flashCards.title: IR (Information Retrieval)
flashCards.definition: Process of obtaining relevant information from a large repository based on user queries.

flashCards.title: Translational
flashCards.definition: Process or approach of converting scientific research into practical applications.

flashCards.title: Adaptive Dual-Scale Denoising
flashCards.definition: Denoising approach designed to balance both local and global feature extraction in models, particularly in the context of diffusion-based generative models.

flashCards.title: Transformative AI
flashCards.definition: AI systems capable of bringing about profound, large-scale changes in society, potentially altering the economy, governance, and even human life itself.

flashCards.title: Similarity Masking
flashCards.definition: Technique used to filter or obscure less important features in data based on their similarity to other features, enhancing the focus on distinct or more relevant aspects for tasks like ML or pattern recognition.

flashCards.title: Memory Extender
flashCards.definition: Techniques or systems designed to enhance the memory capabilities of AI models, enabling them to retain and utilize more information over longer periods.

flashCards.title: BoW (Bag-of-Words)
flashCards.definition: Text representation technique used in NLP to simplify text content by treating it as an unordered set of words.

flashCards.title: Prompt Engineering
flashCards.definition: Process of carefully designing input prompts to elicit desired outputs from language models.

flashCards.title: Classifier
flashCards.definition: ML model that categorizes data into predefined classes.

flashCards.title: xRx
flashCards.definition: Flexible framework designed for building multimodal AI-powered systems that interact with users through a variety of inputs (like text, voice, and more) and outputs, while incorporating advanced reasoning capabilities.

flashCards.title: Spillover
flashCards.definition: Unintended consequences or effects that AI systems can have outside of their designed operational contexts.

flashCards.title: Autonomous Reasoning
flashCards.definition: Capacity of AI systems to make independent decisions or draw conclusions based on logic or data without human intervention.

flashCards.title: Swarm Intelligence
flashCards.definition: Form of AI inspired by the collective behavior of social insects and animals, used to solve complex problems through decentralized, self-organized systems.

flashCards.title: XenoCognition
flashCards.definition: Exploration of cognition and intelligence in non-human entities, both biological and artificial, to broaden understanding of varied cognitive processes.

flashCards.title: Prompt Caching
flashCards.definition: Practice of storing previously used prompts and their corresponding AI-generated outputs to improve efficiency and reduce computational costs in AI systems.

flashCards.title: Proliferation Problem
flashCards.definition: The issue of an overwhelming number of options or paths that an algorithm must consider, making computation impractically complex or resource-intensive.

flashCards.title: Regression
flashCards.definition: Statistical method used in ML to predict a continuous outcome variable based on one or more predictor variables.

flashCards.title: Exocortex
flashCards.definition: External artificial extension of the human brain, designed to augment cognitive functions through advanced computing technologies.

flashCards.title: RNN (Recurrent Neural Network)
flashCards.definition: Class of neural networks where connections between nodes form a directed graph along a temporal sequence, enabling them to exhibit temporal dynamic behavior for a sequence of inputs.

flashCards.title: Predictive Analytics
flashCards.definition: Using statistical techniques and algorithms to analyze historical data and make predictions about future events.

flashCards.title: Validation Data
flashCards.definition: Subset of data used to assess the performance of a model during the training phase, separate from the training data itself.

flashCards.title: MLM (Masked-Language Modeling)
flashCards.definition: Training technique where random words in a sentence are replaced with a special token, and the model learns to predict these masked words based on their context.

flashCards.title: Self-Correction
flashCards.definition: An AI system's ability to recognize and rectify its own mistakes or errors without external intervention.

flashCards.title: Text to Action Model
flashCards.definition: Process of interpreting and converting written or spoken language into executable actions by a system or application.

flashCards.title: Persistency
flashCards.definition: Persistent storage and retrieval of generated data and learned behaviors to maintain a model's performance and ensure its utility over time.

flashCards.title: Speech-to-Text Model
flashCards.definition: A computational model designed to convert spoken language into written text using AI and linguistic pattern recognition.

flashCards.title: VC Dimension (Vapnik-Chervonenkis)
flashCards.definition: Measure of the capacity of a statistical classification algorithm, quantifying how complex the model is in terms of its ability to fit varied sets of data.

flashCards.title: Spatial Intelligence
flashCards.definition: Ability of a system to understand, reason, and manipulate spatial relationships and properties within its environment.

flashCards.title: Frame Problem
flashCards.definition: Challenge in AI of representing and updating the effects of actions in a dynamic world without having to explicitly state all conditions that remain unchanged.

flashCards.title: NLP (Neuro-Linguistic Programming)
flashCards.definition: Techniques and methodologies for understanding and generating human language by computers.

flashCards.title: Alignment
flashCards.definition: Process of ensuring that an AI system's goals and behaviors are consistent with human values and ethics.

flashCards.title: ResNet (Residual Network)
flashCards.definition: Type of CNN (Convolutional Neural Network) architecture that introduces residual learning to facilitate the training of much deeper networks by utilizing shortcut connections or skip connections that allow the gradient to bypass some layers.

flashCards.title: GFlowNet (Generative Flow Networks)
flashCards.definition: Research direction at the intersection of reinforcement learning, deep generative models, and energy-based probabilistic modeling, aimed at improving generative active learning and unsupervised learning.

flashCards.title: EDA (Exploratory Data Analysis)
flashCards.definition: Technique used to analyze data sets to summarize their main characteristics, often with visual methods, before applying more formal modeling.

flashCards.title: Cherry Picking
flashCards.definition: Practice of selectively choosing the most favorable results from multiple outputs generated by an algorithm, often used to present the algorithm in a better light.

flashCards.title: Nowcasting
flashCards.definition: Immediate forecast of economic or environmental conditions based on real-time data evolution using AI models.

flashCards.title: Classification
flashCards.definition: Supervised learning task in ML where the goal is to assign input data to one of several predefined categories.

flashCards.title: Embedding
flashCards.definition: Representations of items, like words, sentences, or objects, in a continuous vector space, facilitating their quantitative comparison and manipulation by AI models.

flashCards.title: Rank Fusion
flashCards.definition: Technique used to combine multiple ranked lists of items, such as search engine results, into a single aggregated ranking that ideally reflects the consensus or most relevant ordering.

flashCards.title: Numerical Processing
flashCards.definition: Algorithms and techniques for handling and analyzing numerical data to extract patterns, make predictions, or understand underlying trends.

flashCards.title: Raven's Progressive Matrices
flashCards.definition: A non-verbal assessment tool commonly used to measure abstract reasoning, which is often regarded as a component of general intelligence.

flashCards.title: ITM (Image-Text Matching)
flashCards.definition: AI technique that involves automatically identifying correspondences between textual descriptions and visual elements within images.

flashCards.title: Interpretability
flashCards.definition: Extent to which a human can understand the cause of a decision made by an AI system.

flashCards.title: Brainoware
flashCards.definition: AI systems designed to emulate the functions and processes of the human brain, focusing on cognitive and neural-inspired computing.

flashCards.title: Denoising
flashCards.definition: Process of removing noise from data, particularly in the context of images and signals, to enhance the quality of the information.

flashCards.title: Attention Projection Matrix
flashCards.definition: Matrix used in attention mechanisms within neural networks, particularly in transformer models, to project input vectors into query, key, and value vectors.

flashCards.title: Hidden Layer
flashCards.definition: Layer of neurons in an artificial neural network that processes inputs from the previous layer, transforming the data before passing it on to the next layer, without direct exposure to the input or output data.

flashCards.title: Expert System
flashCards.definition: Computer program designed to mimic the decision-making abilities of a human expert in a specific domain.

flashCards.title: Attention Block
flashCards.definition: Core component in neural networks, particularly in transformers, designed to selectively focus on the most relevant parts of an input sequence when making predictions.

flashCards.title: Gradient Descent
flashCards.definition: Optimization algorithm used to find the minimum of a function by iteratively moving towards the steepest descent direction.

flashCards.title: GAT (Graph Attention Network)
flashCards.definition: Type of neural network that applies attention mechanisms directly to graphs to dynamically prioritize information from different nodes in the graph.

flashCards.title: Deterministic
flashCards.definition: System or process is one that, given a particular initial state, will always produce the same output or result, with no randomness or unpredictability involved.

flashCards.title: Sample Efficiency
flashCards.definition: Ability of a ML model to achieve high performance with a relatively small number of training samples.

flashCards.title: Lost-in-the-Middle
flashCards.definition: Issue in LLMs where they tend to struggle with retaining and processing information from the middle parts of long input sequences.

flashCards.title: Non-Contrastive
flashCards.definition: ML approach that focuses on learning useful representations of data without explicitly contrasting positive examples against negative examples.

flashCards.title: Siamese Network
flashCards.definition: Type of neural network architecture that involves two or more identical subnetworks sharing the same parameters and weights, typically used for tasks like similarity learning and verification.

flashCards.title: Artefactual Autopoiesis
flashCards.definition: Design and creation of artificial systems capable of self-maintenance and reproduction, mirroring the autopoietic characteristics of living organisms.

flashCards.title: Objective Function
flashCards.definition: Objective function used in ML which quantitatively defines the goal of an optimization problem by measuring the performance of a model or solution.

flashCards.title: Brute Force
flashCards.definition: Straightforward problem-solving approach that systematically enumerates all possible candidates to find a solution.

flashCards.title: Hebbian Learning
flashCards.definition: Neural network learning rule based on the principle that synapses between neurons are strengthened when the neurons activate simultaneously.

flashCards.title: Loss Landscape
flashCards.definition: The topographical representation of a neural network's loss function showcasing the variations in loss values across different parameter settings.

flashCards.title: Contextual Retrieval
flashCards.definition: AI-driven search technique that retrieves information based on the broader context of a query, rather than relying solely on exact keywords or phrases.

flashCards.title: Custom Instructions
flashCards.definition: Directives or rules provided by users to AI systems, tailoring the AI's responses or behaviors to specific needs or contexts.

flashCards.title: NPC (Non-Player Character)
flashCards.definition: Character in a virtual environment that operates under AI control, exhibiting behaviors or responses not directed by human players.

flashCards.title: Ethical AI
flashCards.definition: Practice of creating AI technologies that follow clearly defined ethical guidelines and principles to benefit society while minimizing harm.

flashCards.title: Overfitting
flashCards.definition: When a ML model learns the detail and noise in the training data to the extent that it negatively impacts the performance of the model on new data.

flashCards.title: ASR (Automatic Speech Recognition)
flashCards.definition: Translates spoken language into written text, enabling computers to understand and process human speech.

flashCards.title: SNARC (Stochastic Neural Analog Reinforcement Calculator)
flashCards.definition: Recognized as one of the earliest electronic neural network machines, SNARC simulated a rat navigating a maze using analog components and probabilistic logic.

flashCards.title: Embodied Intelligence
flashCards.definition: Intelligence emerging from the physical interaction of an agent with its environment, emphasizing the importance of a body in learning and cognition.

flashCards.title: FSL (Few-Shot Learning)
flashCards.definition: ML approach that enables models to learn and make accurate predictions from a very small dataset.

flashCards.title: Biocomputer
flashCards.definition: Computational system that uses biological molecules, such as DNA and proteins, to perform data processing and storage tasks.

flashCards.title: Test Time Compute
flashCards.definition: Refers to the computational resources and processes required during the evaluation phase of an AI model on new, unseen data.

flashCards.title: Evolutionary Algorithm
flashCards.definition: Optimization methods inspired by the process of natural selection where potential solutions evolve over generations to optimize a given objective function.

flashCards.title: Activation Beacon
flashCards.definition: Method used in LLMs to extend the context window they can process by employing a technique of condensing and streamlining longer text sequences.

flashCards.title: GMM (Gaussian Mixture Models)
flashCards.definition: Probabilistic models that assume all data points are generated from a mixture of a finite number of Gaussian distributions with unknown parameters.

flashCards.title: Video-to-3D model
flashCards.definition: An AI technique that converts 2D video footage into three-dimensional digital models by analyzing and reconstructing the spatial geometry within the videos.

flashCards.title: ViTs (Vision Transformers)
flashCards.definition: Class of DL models that apply the transformer architecture, originally designed for natural language processing, to computer vision tasks.

flashCards.title: TTFT (Test Time Fine-Tuning)
flashCards.definition: Process of adapting a pre-trained model using new data during the testing phase to improve its performance on specific tasks.

flashCards.title: Query
flashCards.definition: Request made to a data management system or AI model to retrieve information or execute a command based on specific criteria.

flashCards.title: LNN (Liquid Neural Network)
flashCards.definition: Type of artificial neural network designed to process data that changes over time, such as time series data, by simulating a more dynamic and fluid-like behavior.

flashCards.title: WBE (Whole Brain Emulation)
flashCards.definition: Hypothetical process of scanning a biological brain in detail and replicating its state and processes in a computational system to achieve functional and experiential equivalence.

flashCards.title: TRL (Transfer Reinforcement Learning)
flashCards.definition: Subfield of RL focused on leveraging knowledge gained from one or more source tasks to improve learning efficiency and performance in a different, but related, target task.

flashCards.title: AV (Autonomous Vehicles)
flashCards.definition: Self-driving cars that combine sensors, algorithms, and software to navigate and drive without human intervention.

flashCards.title: Optimization Problem
flashCards.definition: Optimization problem in AI which involves finding the best solution from all feasible solutions, given a set of constraints and an objective to achieve or optimize.

flashCards.title: Positional Encoding
flashCards.definition: Technique used in neural network models, especially in transformers, to inject information about the order of tokens in the input sequence.

flashCards.title: Red Queen Effect
flashCards.definition: The continuous need for systems or agents to adapt and evolve just to maintain their relative performance in a competitive or dynamic environment.

flashCards.title: Bayesian Network
flashCards.definition: Graphical model that represents probabilistic relationships among variables using directed acyclic graphs (DAGs).

flashCards.title: Predictive Processing
flashCards.definition: An approach in cognitive science and AI that posits the brain as a hierarchical system constantly predicting sensory input to minimize the difference between expectation and perception.

flashCards.title: Privileged Instructions
flashCards.definition: Commands in computing that can only be executed in a privileged mode, typically restricted to the operating system or other system-level software to manage hardware and critical operations securely.

flashCards.title: Bias
flashCards.definition: Systematic errors in data or algorithms that create unfair outcomes, such as privileging one arbitrary group of users over others.

flashCards.title: Validation Metric
flashCards.definition: A validation metric is used to evaluate the performance of an AI model on a validation dataset, helping determine its accuracy, effectiveness, or other aspects critical to model selection and tuning.

flashCards.title: TTT (Test-Time Training)
flashCards.definition: ML approach where the model adapts itself during the inference phase using auxiliary tasks and additional training data available at test time to improve performance.

flashCards.title: Control Vector
flashCards.definition: Computational mechanism used in AI models to adjust certain characteristics of the model's outputs based on specific parameters or conditions.

flashCards.title: Q-Learning
flashCards.definition: Model-free reinforcement learning algorithm that seeks to learn the value of actions in a given state, enabling an agent to maximize cumulative reward over time.

flashCards.title: AmI (Ambient Intelligence)
flashCards.definition: Electronic environments that are sensitive, adaptive, and responsive to the presence of people, aiming to enhance the quality of life through seamless integration of technology.

flashCards.title: Few Shot
flashCards.definition: ML technique designed to recognize patterns and make predictions based on a very limited amount of training data.

flashCards.title: Active Inference
flashCards.definition: Theoretical framework in neuroscience and artificial intelligence that describes how agents infer and act to minimize their prediction errors about the state of the world.

flashCards.title: ReLU (Rectified Linear Unit)
flashCards.definition: Activation function commonly used in neural networks which outputs the input directly if it is positive, otherwise, it outputs zero.

flashCards.title: CSPs (Constraint Satisfaction Problems)
flashCards.definition: Mathematical problems defined by a set of variables, a domain of values for each variable, and a set of constraints specifying allowable combinations of values.

flashCards.title: OOD (Out Of Distribution Behavior)
flashCards.definition: When an AI model encounters data that significantly differ from its training data, often leading to unreliable or erroneous predictions.

flashCards.title: Enrichment
flashCards.definition: Process of improving raw data quality with supplemental information to enable more accurate and insightful AI models.

flashCards.title: Functional AGI
flashCards.definition: Hypothetical AI technology that possesses the capacity to understand, learn, and apply knowledge across diverse tasks which normally require human intelligence.

flashCards.title: Autopoiesis
flashCards.definition: Systems capable of reproducing and maintaining themselves by regulating their internal environment in response to external conditions.

flashCards.title: Greedy Decoding
flashCards.definition: Technique used in ML models, especially in NLP, where the model selects the most likely next item in a sequence at each step.

flashCards.title: LTPA (Long-Term Planning Agent)
flashCards.definition: AI system designed to make decisions over extended periods, considering future consequences and outcomes.

flashCards.title: Text-to-Image Model
flashCards.definition: Converts descriptive text inputs into visual images through AI-generated interpretations.

flashCards.title: Text-to-Code Model
flashCards.definition: AI models designed to translate natural language descriptions into executable code snippets, facilitating automation in software development and assisting developers.

flashCards.title: Supervised Learning
flashCards.definition: ML approach where models are trained on labeled data to predict outcomes or classify data into categories.

flashCards.title: Agentic AI Systems
flashCards.definition: Advanced AI capable of making decisions and taking actions autonomously to achieve specific goals, embodying characteristics of agency and decision-making usually associated with humans or animals.

flashCards.title: CNN (Convolutional Neural Network)
flashCards.definition: Deep learning algorithm that can capture spatial hierarchies in data, particularly useful for image and video recognition tasks.

flashCards.title: IO (Influence Operations)
flashCards.definition: Strategic actions designed to affect the perceptions, attitudes, and behaviors of target audiences to achieve specific objectives.

flashCards.title: Teacher Committee
flashCards.definition: Group of expert models that collaboratively guide the training process of a student model to improve its performance.

flashCards.title: Neuromorphic Chips
flashCards.definition: Specialized hardware designed to mimic the neural structures and functioning of the human brain to enhance computational efficiency and speed in processing AI algorithms.

flashCards.title: HITL (Human-in-the-Loop)
flashCards.definition: Integration of human judgment into AI systems to improve or guide the decision-making process.

flashCards.title: Byte-Level State Space
flashCards.definition: Representation of the state space of a system or model at the granularity of individual bytes, capturing every possible state a byte can assume within a computational context.

flashCards.title: Symmetry
flashCards.definition: Invariances in data or models where certain transformations do not affect the outcomes or predictions.

flashCards.title: Consciousness Level
flashCards.definition: The measurement or assessment of an AI's ability to demonstrate awareness or understanding akin to human consciousness.

flashCards.title: Linear Algebra
flashCards.definition: Branch of mathematics focusing on vector spaces and linear mappings between these spaces, which is essential for many machine learning algorithms.

flashCards.title: Reversal Curse
flashCards.definition: A situation in AI where improving performance on one task leads to detriments in another, typically due to underlying conflicts in the model's optimization or architecture.

flashCards.title: Semantic Segmentation
flashCards.definition: Process of partitioning a digital image into multiple segments (sets of pixels) to simplify its representation into something more meaningful and easier to analyze, where each segment corresponds to different objects or parts of objects.

flashCards.title: Latent Diffusion Backbone
flashCards.definition: A framework in AI utilizing latent variable models with diffusion processes to generate high-dimensional data from low-dimensional latent representations.

flashCards.title: Continual Pre-Training
flashCards.definition: Process of incrementally training a pre-trained ML model on new data or tasks to update its knowledge without forgetting previously learned information.

flashCards.title: Semi-Supervised Learning
flashCards.definition: ML approach that uses a combination of a small amount of labeled data and a large amount of unlabeled data for training models.

flashCards.title: Stride Length
flashCards.definition: Refers to the number of pixels by which the filter or kernel moves across the input data during convolution operations in convolutional neural networks (CNNs).

flashCards.title: GOFAI (Good Old-Fashioned AI)
flashCards.definition: Traditional approach to AI that relies on symbolic reasoning, logic, and rule-based systems to simulate intelligent behavior.

flashCards.title: Uncensored AI
flashCards.definition: AI systems that operate without restrictions on the content they generate or the decisions they make.

flashCards.title: Algorithm
flashCards.definition: Step-by-step procedure or formula for solving a problem or performing a task.

flashCards.title: Lossy Compression
flashCards.definition: A data encoding method that reduces file size by eliminating some information deemed less important, resulting in a loss of data quality.

flashCards.title: KL (Kullback–Leibler) Divergence
flashCards.definition: Measure of how one probability distribution diverges from a second, reference probability distribution.

flashCards.title: Action Variable
flashCards.definition: Represents a control mechanism within an environment used by AI systems to influence outcomes or states.

flashCards.title: Layer Normalization
flashCards.definition: Technique used in neural networks to normalize the inputs across the features within a layer, improving training stability and model performance, particularly in recurrent and transformer models.

flashCards.title: EM (Expectation-Maximization)
flashCards.definition: Statistical technique used to find the maximum likelihood estimates of parameters in probabilistic models, specifically when the model depends on unobserved latent variables.

flashCards.title: Differential Privacy
flashCards.definition: System for publicly sharing information about a dataset by describing the patterns of groups within the dataset while withholding information about individuals in the dataset.

flashCards.title: PPO (Proximal Policy Optimization)
flashCards.definition: RL algorithm that aims to balance ease of implementation, sample efficiency, and reliable performance by using a simpler but effective update method for policy optimization.

flashCards.title: NMF (Non-Negative Matrix Factorization)
flashCards.definition: Technique in multivariate analysis that factors high-dimensional vectors into a lower-dimensional representation, while preserving the non-negative elements in the data sets.

flashCards.title: Personal Software
flashCards.definition: Software that learns and adapts to individual behaviors in order to infer preferences and aid in task execution.

flashCards.title: LMN (Large Nature Model)
flashCards.definition: Open-source model focused on nature, using a vast, ethically sourced dataset of natural world elements.

flashCards.title: Speech-to-Speech Model
flashCards.definition: Systems that directly convert spoken language into another language through AI, enabling real-time translation and cross-lingual communication.

flashCards.title: Attention Mechanisms
flashCards.definition: Dynamically prioritize certain parts of input data over others, enabling models to focus on relevant information when processing complex data sequences.

flashCards.title: LAM (Large Action Model)
flashCards.definition: Advanced AI systems designed to interpret and execute complex tasks by directly modeling human actions within digital applications.

flashCards.title: Flow Engineering
flashCards.definition: Structured process of improving problem-solving in tasks like code generation by guiding a model through systematic, iterative refinements based on feedback loops.

flashCards.title: RLAIF (Reinforcement Learning with AI Feedback)
flashCards.definition: A method that combines reinforcement learning techniques with feedback derived from AI models to enhance decision-making or control tasks efficiently.

flashCards.title: Boltzmann Machine
flashCards.definition: Stochastic recurrent neural network used to learn and represent complex probability distributions over binary variables.

flashCards.title: AI Governance
flashCards.definition: Set of policies, principles, and practices that guide the ethical development, deployment, and regulation of artificial intelligence technologies.

flashCards.title: Encoder-Decoder Transformer
flashCards.definition: A structure used in NLP for understanding and generating language by encoding input and decoding the output.

flashCards.title: Turing Completeness
flashCards.definition: Systems that can simulate a Turing machine's computational abilities.

flashCards.title: System 1 & System 2
flashCards.definition: 'Two modes of thinking in human cognition: System 1 is fast, automatic, and intuitive, while System 2 is slow, deliberate, and analytical.'

flashCards.title: Data Wall
flashCards.definition: Limitation faced when the available data becomes insufficient for further training or improving machine learning models.

flashCards.title: Hypersphere-Based Transformer
flashCards.definition: An improved framework for transformers focused on enhancing efficiency and performance by leveraging hyperspheres.

flashCards.title: Gödel Code
flashCards.definition: Method of encoding mathematical and logical statements as unique natural numbers, introduced by Kurt Gödel as part of his proof of the incompleteness theorems.

flashCards.title: Lump of Task Fallacy
flashCards.definition: Misconception that a task or series of tasks performed by human intelligence can be replicated entirely by artificial intelligence.

flashCards.title: Model Garden
flashCards.definition: Centralized repository that houses a collection of pre-trained machine learning models designed to be easily accessible and reusable by developers and researchers.

flashCards.title: Universal Learning Algorithms
flashCards.definition: Theoretical frameworks aimed at creating systems capable of learning any task to human-level competency, leveraging principles that could allow for generalization across diverse domains.

flashCards.title: Simulation
flashCards.definition: Process of creating a digital model of a real-world or theoretical situation to study the behavior and dynamics of systems.

flashCards.title: Three Laws of Robotics
flashCards.definition: Set of ethical guidelines designed to govern the behavior of robots and ensure their safe interaction with humans, proposed by science fiction writer Isaac Asimov.

flashCards.title: Value Matrix
flashCards.definition: Structured format for organizing and displaying data, often used in machine learning to represent input data and their corresponding outputs or labels.

flashCards.title: DLMs (Deep Language Models)
flashCards.definition: Advanced ML models designed to understand, generate, and translate human language by leveraging DL techniques.

flashCards.title: Find+Replace Transformers
flashCards.definition: Novel architectural extension of traditional transformers, designed to achieve Turing completeness and enhance model performance on complex tasks.

flashCards.title: Hyperscalers
flashCards.definition: Large tech organizations that design and manage infrastructure to support the massive scale of big data, AI and cloud computing.

flashCards.title: Ensemble Learning
flashCards.definition: ML paradigm where multiple models (often called weak learners) are trained to solve the same problem and combined to improve the accuracy of predictions.

flashCards.title: Recursive Self-Improvement
flashCards.definition: Process by which an AI system iteratively improves itself, enhancing its intelligence and capabilities without human intervention.

flashCards.title: Neurode
flashCards.definition: A conceptual element used as a simplified model for neurons in AI and neural networks, facilitating the construction of algorithms that mimic neurological behavior.

flashCards.title: Perceptron
flashCards.definition: Model in neural networks designed to perform binary classification tasks by mimicking the decision-making process of a single neuron.

flashCards.title: Forward Propagation
flashCards.definition: Process in a neural network where input data is passed through layers of the network to generate output.

flashCards.title: Autoregressive
flashCards.definition: Statistical algorithms used in time series forecasting, where future values are predicted based on a weighted sum of past observations.

flashCards.title: Surprisal
flashCards.definition: Measures the amount of unexpectedness or information content associated with a specific outcome in a probabilistic event.

flashCards.title: Spacetime Patches
flashCards.definition: Technique for transforming video data into a format suitable for ML models by breaking down video into temporal and spatial segments.

flashCards.title: Encoder-Decoder Models
flashCards.definition: Class of deep learning architectures that process an input to generate a corresponding output.

flashCards.title: Fast Weights
flashCards.definition: Fast weights are temporary, rapidly changing parameters in neural networks designed to capture transient patterns or short-term dependencies in data.

flashCards.title: Internal Representation
flashCards.definition: The way information is structured and stored within an AI system, enabling the system to process, reason, or make decisions.

flashCards.title: Chunking
flashCards.definition: A concept in cognitive psychology and AI, where information is broken down and grouped into chunks to simplify complex data and optimize memory usage.

flashCards.title: Grokking
flashCards.definition: Refers to the process of deeply understanding something intuitively and completely, often used in AI to describe achieving a profound comprehension of complex concepts or systems.

flashCards.title: Probabilistic Programming
flashCards.definition: Programming paradigm designed to handle uncertainty and probabilistic models, allowing for the creation of programs that can make inferences about data by incorporating statistical methods directly into the code.

flashCards.title: SAM (Segment Anything Model)
flashCards.definition: AI model designed for high-precision image segmentation, capable of identifying and delineating every object within an image.

flashCards.title: Point-wise Feedforward Network
flashCards.definition: Neural network layer that applies a series of linear and non-linear transformations to each position (or "point") in the input sequence independently.

flashCards.title: Negative References
flashCards.definition: Mechanisms that prevent or mitigate undesirable, biased, or harmful outputs from AI models during text generation, aligned with ethical AI practices.

flashCards.title: Skill Differential
flashCards.definition: Variation in performance levels between individuals or groups due to differences in skills, experience, or knowledge, particularly within the same task or profession.

flashCards.title: Deep SSMs (Deep State-Space Models)
flashCards.definition: Advanced methodologies combining deep learning with state-space models to model complex dynamic systems characterized by sequences of observations.

flashCards.title: Machine Understanding
flashCards.definition: Capability of AI systems to interpret and comprehend data, text, images, or situations in a manner akin to human understanding.

flashCards.title: Mechanistic Interpretability
flashCards.definition: Study and methods used to understand the specific causal mechanisms through which AI models produce their outputs.

flashCards.title: Moat
flashCards.definition: A concept of competitive advantage that AI companies gain by developing proprietary data, algorithms, and models.

flashCards.title: NLU (Natural Language Understanding)
flashCards.definition: Subfield of NLP focused on enabling machines to understand and interpret human language in a way that is both meaningful and contextually relevant.

flashCards.title: Attention Network
flashCards.definition: Type of neural network that dynamically focuses on specific parts of the input data, enhancing the performance of tasks like language translation, image recognition, and more.

flashCards.title: Comparative Advantage
flashCards.definition: Strategic advantage that a particular AI model, system, or approach has over others in performing specific tasks more efficiently or effectively due to unique strengths or capabilities.

flashCards.title: Mixture Map
flashCards.definition: Graphical representation used in data science and ML to visualize the relationships and interactions between different components or features of a dataset.

flashCards.title: Ngram
flashCards.definition: Contiguous sequence of N items from a given sample of text or speech.

flashCards.title: Instrumentation
flashCards.definition: Techniques and tools used to monitor, measure, and analyze the performance and behavior of AI systems.

flashCards.title: PDS (Psychological Depth Scale)
flashCards.definition: Tool used to measure the complexity and depth of an individual's psychological experiences and inner life.

flashCards.title: DQN (Deep Q-Networks)
flashCards.definition: RL technique that combines Q-learning with deep neural networks to enable agents to learn how to make optimal decisions from high-dimensional sensory inputs.

flashCards.title: WHAM (World and Human Action Model)
flashCards.definition: Multimodal, highly interactive 3D environment for developing and testing AI models.

flashCards.title: NAS (Neural Architecture Search)
flashCards.definition: Automated process that designs optimal neural network architectures for specific tasks.

flashCards.title: QML (Quantum Machine Learning)
flashCards.definition: Integration of quantum algorithms within ML models to improve computational speed and data handling abilities.

flashCards.title: 1-N Systems
flashCards.definition: Architectures where one input or controller manages multiple outputs or agents, applicable in fields like neural networks and robotics.

flashCards.title: Capability Control
flashCards.definition: Strategies and mechanisms implemented to ensure that AI systems act within desired limits, preventing them from performing actions that are undesired or harmful to humans.

flashCards.title: Variational Free Energy
flashCards.definition: A mathematical framework used to approximate complex probability distributions, commonly employed in AI to optimize models and infer latent variables.

flashCards.title: Weight Initialization
flashCards.definition: An essential process in neural network training that involves setting the initial values of the model's weights to influence learning effectiveness and convergence.

flashCards.title: Sparse Crosscoders
flashCards.definition: A technique in AI aimed at improving the efficiency of model training and inference by using sparse connections between layers rather than dense connections.

flashCards.title: Semantic Entropy
flashCards.definition: Measure of uncertainty or unpredictability in the meaning of a message or data, often considering the context in which the information is used.

flashCards.title: De-Biasing
flashCards.definition: Methods and practices used to reduce or eliminate biases in AI systems, aiming to make the systems more fair, equitable, and representative of diverse populations.

flashCards.title: Underfitting
flashCards.definition: Occurs when a ML model is too simple to capture the underlying pattern of the data it is trained on, resulting in poor performance on both training and testing datasets.

flashCards.title: Fine Tuning
flashCards.definition: Method used in ML to adjust the parameters of an already trained model to improve its accuracy on a specific, often smaller, dataset.

flashCards.title: Matrix Multiplication
flashCards.definition: An algebraic operation that takes two matrices and produces a new matrix, fundamental in various AI and ML algorithms.

flashCards.title: VLM (Visual Language Model)
flashCards.definition: AI models designed to interpret and generate content by integrating visual and textual information, enabling them to perform tasks like image captioning, visual question answering, and more.

flashCards.title: Diffusion
flashCards.definition: Class of generative models used to create high-quality, diverse samples of data by iteratively adding and then reversing noise.

flashCards.title: NHI (Non-Human Intelligence)
flashCards.definition: Intelligence systems that operate independently of human intelligence, encompassing a broad range of entities and origins, emphasizing capabilities that may surpass human cognitive processes.

flashCards.title: PFGM (Poisson Flow Generative Model)
flashCards.definition: Generative model that utilizes Poisson processes in its architecture to model and generate complex data distributions.

flashCards.title: Targeted Adversarial Examples
flashCards.definition: Inputs intentionally designed to cause a machine learning model to misclassify them into a specific, incorrect category.

flashCards.title: Prompt Injection
flashCards.definition: Technique used to manipulate or influence the behavior of AI models by inserting specific commands or cues into the input prompt.

flashCards.title: Scale Separation
flashCards.definition: Distinguishing between phenomena or variables that operate on distinctly different magnitudes, time scales, or spatial dimensions.

flashCards.title: Chunking Strategy
flashCards.definition: Method of grouping similar pieces of information together to simplify processing and enhance memory performance.

flashCards.title: Indirect Manipulation
flashCards.definition: An interaction technique where users influence system tasks and behaviors through intermediary or abstract operations, deviating from direct interaction.

flashCards.title: Steerability
flashCards.definition: Ability to intentionally manipulate the output of the network in a specific direction by applying predetermined modifications to its inputs or parameters.

flashCards.title: Top-K
flashCards.definition: Method in ML and information retrieval where the system selects the k most relevant or highest-scoring items from a larger set of predictions or results.

flashCards.title: Eval (Evaluation)
flashCards.definition: Process of assessing the performance and effectiveness of an AI model or algorithm based on specified criteria and datasets.

flashCards.title: Attention
flashCards.definition: Refers to mechanisms that allow models to dynamically focus on specific parts of input data, enhancing the relevance and context-awareness of the processing.

flashCards.title: Attention Seeking
flashCards.definition: A behavior exhibited by neural networks, where they dynamically focus computational resources on important parts of the input, enhancing learning and performance.

flashCards.title: Structured Generation
flashCards.definition: Process where outputs are produced in a structured format, often requiring adherence to specific formats or templates, such as tables, graphs, or well-organized textual reports.

flashCards.title: Connectionist AI
flashCards.definition: Set of computational models in AI that simulate the human brain's network of neurons to process information and learn from data.

flashCards.title: Singularity
flashCards.definition: Hypothetical future point at which technological growth becomes uncontrollable and irreversible, resulting in unforeseeable changes to human civilization.

flashCards.title: Implicit Reasoning
flashCards.definition: Ability of a system to make inferences and draw conclusions that are not explicitly programmed or directly stated in the input data.

flashCards.title: Dijkstra's Algorithm
flashCards.definition: An algorithm designed to find the shortest path between nodes in a graph, which is widely used in AI for optimizing traversals across networks and structures.

flashCards.title: Convergent Learning
flashCards.definition: Process by which a ML model consistently arrives at the same solution or prediction given the same input data, despite variations in initial conditions or configurations.

flashCards.title: Statistical Computing
flashCards.definition: Utilization of computational algorithms and statistical techniques to model, analyze, and interpret complex data effectively.

flashCards.title: Speculative Decoding
flashCards.definition: AI technique that generates multiple potential outputs simultaneously to improve efficiency and accuracy in tasks like language modeling and neural network inference.

flashCards.title: Moravec's Paradox
flashCards.definition: Moravec's Paradox observes that tasks requiring high-level reasoning are easier for computers, while tasks humans find simple, like perception and mobility, are difficult for AI.

flashCards.title: Saturation Effect
flashCards.definition: Phenomenon where the performance improvements of a model diminish as the complexity of the model or the amount of training data increases beyond a certain point.

flashCards.title: Causal Inference
flashCards.definition: Process of determining the cause-and-effect relationship between variables.

flashCards.title: Frontier Models
flashCards.definition: The most advanced and powerful AI models currently available, pushing the boundaries of AI capabilities towards achieving general intelligence.

flashCards.title: OOMs (Orders of Magnitude)
flashCards.definition: Way to understand and compare quantities in terms of their scale or size, typically using powers of ten.

flashCards.title: Word Vector
flashCards.definition: Numerical representations of words that capture their meanings, relationships, and context within a language.

flashCards.title: BNNs (Biological Neural Networks)
flashCards.definition: Complex networks of neurons found in biological organisms, responsible for processing and transmitting information through electrical and chemical signals.

flashCards.title: Post-Training
flashCards.definition: Techniques and adjustments applied to neural networks after their initial training phase to enhance performance, efficiency, or adaptability to new data or tasks.

flashCards.title: Control Logic
flashCards.definition: Decision-making processes within a system that manage and dictate how various components respond to inputs, aiming to achieve desired outcomes or maintain specific conditions.

flashCards.title: Rejection Sampling
flashCards.definition: Method used to generate samples from a probability distribution by proposing candidates from a simpler distribution and accepting or rejecting them based on a criterion related to the target distribution.

flashCards.title: Gabor Function
flashCards.definition: Mathematical tool used in image processing and signal analysis, known for its ability to localize information in both the spatial and frequency domains simultaneously.

flashCards.title: Instruction Tuning
flashCards.definition: Process used in ML to optimize a language model’s responses for specific tasks by fine-tuning it on a curated set of instructions and examples.

flashCards.title: Artificial Curiosity
flashCards.definition: Algorithmic mechanism in AI that motivates the system's behavior to learn inquisitively and explore unfamiliar environments.

flashCards.title: Graph Theory
flashCards.definition: Field of mathematics and computer science focusing on the properties of graphs, which are structures made up of vertices (or nodes) connected by edges.

flashCards.title: State Space Model
flashCards.definition: Mathematical frameworks used to represent systems that are governed by a set of latent (hidden) variables evolving over time, observed through another set of variables.

flashCards.title: Foundation Model
flashCards.definition: Type of large-scale pre-trained model that can be adapted to a wide range of tasks without needing to be trained from scratch each time.

flashCards.title: Model Drift
flashCards.definition: Change in the underlying data patterns that a ML model was trained on, leading to a decrease in the model's accuracy and effectiveness over time.

flashCards.title: Reversal Course
flashCards.definition: A practiced approach in AI training where learning direction is strategically changed to optimize model performance and mitigate issues like vanishing gradients.

flashCards.title: End-to-End Learning
flashCards.definition: ML approach where a system is trained to directly map input data to the desired output, minimizing the need for manual feature engineering.

flashCards.title: Structured Search
flashCards.definition: Method of querying and retrieving information from databases and other structured data sources where data is organized in defined types and relationships.

flashCards.title: Continuous Learning
flashCards.definition: Systems and models that learn incrementally from a stream of data, updating their knowledge without forgetting previous information.

flashCards.title: Gating Mechanism
flashCards.definition: Control function that regulates the flow of information through the model, deciding what information to keep, discard, or update.

flashCards.title: Algorithmic Bias
flashCards.definition: Systematic and unfair discrimination embedded in the outcomes of algorithms, often reflecting prejudices present in the training data or design process.

flashCards.title: Abductive Reasoning
flashCards.definition: Form of logical inference that starts with an observation and seeks the simplest and most likely explanation for it.

flashCards.title: P(Doom)
flashCards.definition: Probability of an existential catastrophe, often discussed within the context of AI safety and risk assessment.

flashCards.title: Observability
flashCards.definition: Capability to monitor and understand the internal states of an AI system through its outputs.

flashCards.title: Tunable Parameters
flashCards.definition: Variables in an AI model that are adjusted during training to optimize the model's performance on a given task.

flashCards.title: Capability Ladder
flashCards.definition: Conceptual framework used to describe the progression of an AI system's abilities from simple, specific tasks to complex, general tasks.

flashCards.title: Perceptual Domain
flashCards.definition: Range of sensory inputs and interpretations that an AI system can process, akin to human perception systems such as vision, hearing, and touch.

flashCards.title: Exploit Generator
flashCards.definition: Automated software used in AI systems to find and exploit vulnerabilities in other software.

flashCards.title: Model-Based Classifier
flashCards.definition: ML algorithm that uses a pre-defined statistical model to make predictions based on input data.

flashCards.title: Learnability
flashCards.definition: Capacity of an algorithm or model to effectively learn from data, often measured by how well it can generalize from training data to unseen data.

flashCards.title: Image Recognition
flashCards.definition: Ability of AI to identify objects, places, people, writing, and actions in images.

flashCards.title: Universality
flashCards.definition: Concept that certain computational systems can simulate any other computational system, given the correct inputs and enough time and resources.

flashCards.title: Covariance
flashCards.definition: How much two random variables change together

flashCards.title: Situational Models
flashCards.definition: Cognitive frameworks that allow AI systems to understand and predict dynamic environments by continuously integrating contextual information.

flashCards.title: Reasoning Path
flashCards.definition: Logical steps or sequence of inferences made by an AI model or system to arrive at a conclusion, decision, or solution.

flashCards.title: Overparameterized
flashCards.definition: ML model that has more parameters than the number of data points available for training.

flashCards.title: RL (Reinforcement Learning)
flashCards.definition: Type of ML where an agent learns to make decisions by performing actions in an environment to achieve a goal, guided by rewards.

flashCards.title: Edge Model
flashCards.definition: A type of AI model designed to process data directly on the device it was collected from, limiting the need for data transfer.

flashCards.title: Unsupervised Learning
flashCards.definition: Type of ML where algorithms learn patterns from untagged data, without any guidance on what outcomes to predict.

flashCards.title: Perceptual Hash Algorithm
flashCards.definition: Generates a unique hash that reflects the visual or auditory similarity of data, such as an image, rather than its exact content.

flashCards.title: BCI (Brain Computer Interface)
flashCards.definition: Enables direct communication pathways between the brain and external devices, allowing for control of computers or prosthetics with neural activity.

flashCards.title: Training Cost
flashCards.definition: Quantifies the resources required to develop AI models, including computational expenses, energy consumption, and human expertise.

flashCards.title: Scaling Hypothesis
flashCards.definition: Enlarging model size, data, and computational resources can consistently improve task performance up to very large scales.

flashCards.title: Hybrid AI
flashCards.definition: Combines symbolic AI (rule-based systems) and sub-symbolic AI (machine learning) approaches to leverage the strengths of both for more versatile and explainable AI systems.

flashCards.title: Epistemic Foraging
flashCards.definition: Process of actively seeking out new information to reduce uncertainty in an agent's understanding of the world, often driven by curiosity or the need to update beliefs about the environment.

flashCards.title: Policy Gradient Algorithm
flashCards.definition: Type of RL algorithm that optimizes the policy directly by computing gradients of expected rewards with respect to policy parameters.

flashCards.title: Long-Context Modeling
flashCards.definition: Techniques and architectures designed to process and understand sequences of data that are significantly longer than those typically handled by conventional models, enabling better performance on tasks requiring extended context.

flashCards.title: DP (Dynamic Programming)
flashCards.definition: Method used in computer science and mathematics to solve complex problems by breaking them down into simpler subproblems and solving each of these subproblems just once, storing their solutions.

flashCards.title: Perplexity
flashCards.definition: Measure used in language modeling to evaluate how well a model predicts a sample of text, quantifying the model's uncertainty in its predictions.

flashCards.title: Machine Unlearning
flashCards.definition: Process by which an ML model is systematically modified to forget specific data, ensuring that the data no longer influences the model's behavior or decisions.

flashCards.title: Bellman Equation
flashCards.definition: Recursive formula used to find the optimal policy in decision-making processes, particularly in the context of dynamic programming and RL.

flashCards.title: MTL (Multi-Task Learning)
flashCards.definition: ML approach where a single model is trained simultaneously on multiple related tasks, leveraging commonalities and differences across tasks to improve generalization.

flashCards.title: 3D-to-3D Model
flashCards.definition: A computational model that transforms three-dimensional data into another 3D format, typically involving tasks like transformation, enhancement, or generation of new 3D structures.

flashCards.title: Federated Learning
flashCards.definition: ML approach enabling models to be trained across multiple decentralized devices or servers holding local data samples, without exchanging them.

flashCards.title: FSDP (Fully Sharded Data Parallel)
flashCards.definition: Distributed training method in deep learning that divides both model parameters and optimizer states across multiple devices to improve efficiency and scalability.

flashCards.title: Mechanistic Unlearning
flashCards.definition: A process in AI where specific information is selectively removed from trained models to prevent specific outputs or behaviors.

flashCards.title: TensorFlow
flashCards.definition: Open-source software library for machine learning, developed by Google, used for designing, building, and training deep learning models.

flashCards.title: Cross-Attention
flashCards.definition: Mechanism in neural networks that allows the model to weigh and integrate information from different input sources dynamically.

flashCards.title: Loss Function
flashCards.definition: Quantifies the difference between the predicted values by a model and the actual values, serving as a guide for model optimization.

flashCards.title: Speech-to-Image model
flashCards.definition: Transforms spoken language into corresponding visual representations, utilizing AI to bridge auditory and visual domains.

flashCards.title: Speculative Edits
flashCards.definition: Proactive generation of multiple possible edits in a computational process, typically by a system anticipating future states or changes in data before they occur, in order to improve efficiency.

flashCards.title: Utility Function
flashCards.definition: Mathematical tool utilized in AI to model preferences and calculate the best decision based on expected outcomes.

flashCards.title: Adversarial Debiasing
flashCards.definition: ML technique aimed at reducing bias in models by using adversarial training, where one network tries to predict sensitive attributes and another tries to prevent it.

flashCards.title: ToM (Theory of Mind)
flashCards.definition: Cognitive ability to attribute mental states—such as beliefs, intentions, desires, and knowledge—to oneself and others, allowing one to understand that others have perspectives and intentions that differ from one's own.

flashCards.title: VAE (Variational Autoencoders)
flashCards.definition: Class of generative models that use neural networks to encode inputs into a latent space and then decode from this space to reconstruct the input or generate new data that resemble the input data.

flashCards.title: System Prompt
flashCards.definition: Predefined message or question generated by an AI system to guide or solicit a response from the user.

flashCards.title: Performance Degradation
flashCards.definition: Decline in the efficiency or effectiveness of an AI system over time or under specific conditions, leading to reduced accuracy, speed, or reliability.

flashCards.title: Fairness-Aware Machine Learning
flashCards.definition: Focuses on developing algorithms that ensure equitable treatment and outcomes across different demographic groups.

flashCards.title: Policy-Guided Diffusion
