flashCards.definition: Method where a policy, typically learned via RL, guides the diffusion process in generating samples that conform to desired specifications or constraints.

flashCards.title: Local Weight Sharing
flashCards.definition: Technique where the same weights are used across different positions in an input, enhancing the network's ability to recognize patterns irrespective of their spatial location.

flashCards.title: Jailbreaking
flashCards.definition: Exploiting vulnerabilities in AI systems to bypass restrictions and unlock otherwise inaccessible functionalities.

flashCards.title: Weight
flashCards.definition: Represents a coefficient for a feature in a model that determines the influence of that feature on the model's predictions.

flashCards.title: Agent-to-Agent Interaction
flashCards.definition: Communication and cooperation between autonomous agents within a multi-agent system to achieve individual or collective goals.

flashCards.title: GCC (General Computer Control)
flashCards.definition: Ability of an AI system to autonomously manage and utilize a wide range of computer software and systems without specific programming for each individual task.

flashCards.title: MLLMs (Multimodal Large Language Models)
flashCards.definition: Advanced AI systems capable of understanding and generating information across different forms of data, such as text, images, and audio.

flashCards.title: Meta-Classifier
flashCards.definition: Algorithm that combines multiple ML models to improve prediction accuracy over individual models.

flashCards.title: Centaur
flashCards.definition: Collaborative system where humans and AI work together, combining human intuition and expertise with AI's computational power and data processing capabilities.

flashCards.title: FSA (Finite State Automata)
flashCards.definition: Computational model that processes input sequences and transitions between a finite number of states according to a set of rules, typically used for recognizing patterns or designing digital circuits.

flashCards.title: Slop
flashCards.definition: Colloquial slang referring to responses generated by LLMs that may be overly verbose or repetitive, often observed in AI-generated summaries or answers, and sometimes criticized for lacking conciseness or relevance.

flashCards.title: bGPT (Byte-Level Transformer)
flashCards.definition: Variant of the GPT architecture designed to process data at the byte level rather than at the word or sub-word level, allowing for greater flexibility in handling diverse text types and structures.

flashCards.title: Boolean
flashCards.definition: Based on Boolean algebra, involving binary variables representing true or false, essential for logic operations in AI systems.

flashCards.title: Scaffolding
flashCards.definition: Method of gradually building up the complexity of tasks or learning environments to help an AI system develop more sophisticated capabilities over time.

flashCards.title: MMLU (Massive Multitask Language Understanding)
flashCards.definition: Evaluation framework designed to assess the performance of language models across a broad spectrum of tasks and domains.

flashCards.title: RFM (Robotics Foundational Model)
flashCards.definition: Base model designed to provide fundamental capabilities or understanding for the development of various robotic systems and applications.

flashCards.title: Temperature
flashCards.definition: Hyperparameter that controls the randomness of predictions by adjusting the probability distribution of the output classes to make the model's predictions more or less deterministic.

flashCards.title: Graph Machine Learning
flashCards.definition: AI field that applies ML techniques to graph-structured data, enabling the analysis and prediction of relationships and behaviors among interconnected nodes.

flashCards.title: Saturating Non-Linearities
flashCards.definition: Activation functions in neural networks that reach a point where their output changes very little, or not at all, in response to large input values.

flashCards.title: AI Safety
flashCards.definition: Field of research aimed at ensuring AI technologies are beneficial and do not pose harm to humanity.

flashCards.title: Hyperparameter
flashCards.definition: Configuration settings used to structure ML models, which guide the learning process and are set before training begins.

flashCards.title: Silicon-Based Intelligence
flashCards.definition: Concept of artificial intelligence systems that operate on silicon-based hardware, contrasting with biological, carbon-based forms of intelligence such as humans.

flashCards.title: ASI (Artificial Super Intelligence)
flashCards.definition: Hypothetical form of AI that surpasses human intelligence across all domains, including creativity, general wisdom, and problem-solving capabilities.

flashCards.title: Weight Decay
flashCards.definition: Regularization technique used in training neural networks to prevent overfitting by penalizing large weights.

flashCards.title: Similarity Search
flashCards.definition: Method used in data science to identify similar items from a large dataset based on their proximity to a given query item (also known as proximity search).

flashCards.title: Dimension Returns
flashCards.definition: The output shape or size of the dimensions in a dataset, matrix, or tensor after a specific operation is performed, which is critical in ensuring proper alignment and compatibility in machine learning models.

flashCards.title: Trajectory Generation
flashCards.definition: Computational methods for designing the path that an object or agent should follow to reach a destination efficiently and effectively.

flashCards.title: Metaheuristic
flashCards.definition: High-level problem-independent algorithmic framework that provides a set of guidelines or strategies to develop heuristic optimization algorithms.

flashCards.title: Uncertainty Reduction
flashCards.definition: A process in AI by which systems manage and diminish uncertainty in predictions and decisions to improve performance and reliability.

flashCards.title: IFEval (Instruction-Following Eval)
flashCards.definition: Methodology designed to assess the ability of AI systems to follow and execute human-given instructions accurately and effectively.

flashCards.title: Flash Attention
flashCards.definition: GPU-optimized attention mechanism designed to efficiently handle extremely large sequences of data in neural networks.

flashCards.title: Masking
flashCards.definition: Technique used in NLP models to prevent future input tokens from influencing the prediction of current tokens.

flashCards.title: DSS (Decision Support System)
flashCards.definition: A computerized program used to support determinations, judgments, and courses of action in an organization or a business.

flashCards.title: Safety Net
flashCards.definition: Measures, policies, and technologies designed to prevent, detect, and mitigate adverse outcomes or ethical issues stemming from AI systems' operation.

flashCards.title: Open Weights
flashCards.definition: Access to model parameters of AI/ML systems, enabling transparency and collaboration in development and research.

flashCards.title: Federated Analytics
flashCards.definition: An approach that uses machine learning algorithms to analyze decentralized data sources while constantly preserving the privacy and security of the data.

flashCards.title: GNN (Graph Neural Networks)
flashCards.definition: Type of neural network designed for processing data represented in graph form, capturing relationships and structure within the data.

flashCards.title: Embodied AI
flashCards.definition: Integration of AI into physical entities, enabling these systems to interact with the real world through sensory inputs and actions.

flashCards.title: Dimensionality Reduction
flashCards.definition: Process used in ML to reduce the number of input variables or features in a dataset, simplifying models while retaining essential information.

flashCards.title: Fuzzy Logic
flashCards.definition: A method of reasoning that resembles human decision-making by handling imprecise or vague data.

flashCards.title: Training Objective
flashCards.definition: Defines the criterion or goal used to guide the learning process of a machine learning model, often by minimizing or maximizing a particular function during training.

flashCards.title: Loss Optimization
flashCards.definition: Process of adjusting a model's parameters to minimize the difference between the predicted outputs and the actual outputs, measured by a loss function.

flashCards.title: KV (Key-Value)
flashCards.definition: Data storage model where data is stored as a collection of key-value pairs, where each key is unique and maps directly to a value.

flashCards.title: Naive Bayesian Model
flashCards.definition: Probabilistic classifier that assumes strong (naive) independence between the features of a dataset.

flashCards.title: Decidability
flashCards.definition: Whether a problem can be algorithmically solved, meaning there exists a clear procedure (algorithm) that will determine a yes-or-no answer for any given input within a finite amount of time.

flashCards.title: Computational Creativity
flashCards.definition: The study and building of software and algorithms that exhibit behaviors deemed creative in humans, such as generating original artwork, music, or solving problems in unique ways.

flashCards.title: Straight-Through Estimator
flashCards.definition: Technique used in training neural networks to enable the backpropagation of gradients through non-differentiable functions or operations.

flashCards.title: God in a Box
flashCards.definition: AI systems or models that are so powerful and advanced that they could theoretically solve any problem or fulfill any command, but are contained within strict controls to prevent unintended consequences.

flashCards.title: Multiagent
flashCards.definition: Multiple autonomous entities (agents) interacting in a shared environment, often with cooperative or competitive objectives.

flashCards.title: Quantization
flashCards.definition: Process of reducing the precision of the weights and activations in neural network models to decrease their memory and computational requirements.

flashCards.title: SotA (State of the Art)
flashCards.definition: The highest level of performance achieved in a specific field, particularly in AI, where it denotes the most advanced model or algorithm.

flashCards.title: Persuasive System
flashCards.definition: Type of software designed to change a person's attitude or behavior through persuasion and social influence.

flashCards.title: Multi-headed Attention
flashCards.definition: Mechanism in neural networks that allows the model to jointly attend to information from different representation subspaces at different positions.

flashCards.title: TCN (Temporal Convolutional Networks)
flashCards.definition: Type of neural network designed to handle sequential data by applying convolutional operations over time.

flashCards.title: SNN (Spiking Neural Network)
flashCards.definition: Type of artificial neural network that mimics the way biological neural networks in the brain process information, using spikes of electrical activity to transmit and process information.

flashCards.title: Sparse Autoencoder
flashCards.definition: Type of neural network designed to learn efficient data representations by enforcing sparsity on the hidden layer activations.

flashCards.title: Q-Value
flashCards.definition: Measure used in RL to represent the expected future rewards that an agent can obtain, starting from a given state and choosing a particular action.

flashCards.title: Manifold Learning
flashCards.definition: Type of non-linear dimensionality reduction technique used to uncover the underlying structure of high-dimensional data by assuming it lies on a lower-dimensional manifold.

flashCards.title: Feature Extraction
flashCards.definition: Process of transforming raw data into a set of features that are more meaningful and informative for a specific task, such as classification or prediction.

flashCards.title: Adapter
flashCards.definition: Lightweight, modular component added to a pre-trained model to fine-tune it for specific tasks without altering the original model's parameters significantly.

flashCards.title: ACPs (Access Control Policies)
flashCards.definition: Guidelines that regulates who or what can view or use resources in a computing environment.

flashCards.title: GAIL (Generative Adversarial Imitation Learning)
flashCards.definition: Advanced ML technique that uses adversarial training to enable an agent to learn behaviors directly from expert demonstrations without requiring explicit reward signals.

flashCards.title: Data Augmentation
flashCards.definition: Techniques used to increase the size and improve the quality of training datasets for machine learning models without collecting new data.

flashCards.title: Query Flock
flashCards.definition: Method to manage and process multiple related queries simultaneously, improving efficiency and response time.

flashCards.title: nGPT (Normalized Transformer)
flashCards.definition: Model architecture used in NLP, bringing significant efficiency in training and improvements in model robustness.

flashCards.title: Generative Model
flashCards.definition: A type of AI model that learns to generate new data instances that mimic the training data distribution.

flashCards.title: Boosting
flashCards.definition: ML ensemble technique that combines multiple weak learners to form a strong learner, aiming to improve the accuracy of predictions.

flashCards.title: GIGO (Garbage In, Garbage Out)
flashCards.definition: Concept that emphasizes the quality of output is determined by the quality of input data.

flashCards.title: JEPA (Joint Embedding Predictive Architecture)
flashCards.definition: An approach that involves jointly embedding and predicting spatial or temporal correlations within data to improve model performance in tasks like prediction and understanding.

flashCards.title: Overparameterization Regime
flashCards.definition: A phase in ML where the model has more parameters than the number of training samples, often leading to a high-variance, overfitted model.

flashCards.title: Sample Difficulty
flashCards.definition: Degrees of complexities or challenges associated with particular samples or data points in a data set.

flashCards.title: Hyperplane
flashCards.definition: Mathematical concept that represents a subspace in n-dimensional space, with one dimension less than the space itself, used extensively to separate data points in various dimensions.

flashCards.title: Program Induction
flashCards.definition: A process in AI where computers generate, or 'induce', programs based on provided data and specific output criteria.

flashCards.title: XAI (Explainable AI)
flashCards.definition: AI systems designed to provide insights into their behavior and decisions, making them transparent and understandable to humans.

flashCards.title: Local Pooling
flashCards.definition: Process that reduces the spatial dimensions of input data by aggregating information in local regions to create more abstract representations.

flashCards.title: Solomonoff Induction
flashCards.definition: Theory of prediction that combines elements of algorithmic information theory and Bayesian inference to create a universal framework for inferring future data from past observations.

flashCards.title: Mortal Computation
flashCards.definition: Novel concept in computing that integrates the hardware-software relationship more closely, where computational systems are designed to reflect biological principles, particularly mortality and adaptability.

flashCards.title: SCM (Continuous-Time Consistency Model)
flashCards.definition: A framework focused on ensuring consistency within distributed systems by reconciling time discrepancies in data states continuously.

flashCards.title: Foom
flashCards.definition: Hypothetical rapid and uncontrollable growth of an AI's capabilities, leading to a superintelligent entity in a very short period.

flashCards.title: Inference Acceleration
flashCards.definition: Methods and hardware optimizations employed to increase the speed and efficiency of the inference process in machine learning models, particularly neural networks.

flashCards.title: World Model
flashCards.definition: Internal representation that an AI system uses to simulate the environment it operates in, enabling prediction and decision-making based on those simulations.

flashCards.title: Adversarial Attacks
flashCards.definition: Manipulating input data to deceive machine learning models, causing them to make incorrect predictions or classifications.

flashCards.title: Mode Collapse
flashCards.definition: Phenomenon in Generative Adversarial Networks (GANs) where the generator produces limited, highly similar outputs, ignoring the diversity of the target data distribution.

flashCards.title: TESCREAL
flashCards.definition: 'Seven ideologies: Transhumanism, Extropianism, Singularitarianism, Cosmism, Rationalism, Effective Altruism, and Longtermism. They all focus on using technology to improve people’s lives and they are deeply influential among people working on AGI.'

flashCards.title: Bagging
flashCards.definition: ML ensemble technique that improves the stability and accuracy of machine learning algorithms by combining multiple models trained on different subsets of the same data set.

flashCards.title: MIMS (Multiple Instance Learning for Missing Annotations)
flashCards.definition: ML approach where training occurs on labeled bags of instances instead of individual instances, particularly useful when exact annotations are missing.

flashCards.title: MRL (Matryoshka Representation Learning)
flashCards.definition: ML approach under the umbrella of representation learning, which aims to construct hierarchical representations of data, akin to the nesting structure of Russian matryoshka dolls.

flashCards.title: Secure Enclave
flashCards.definition: Hardware-based security feature designed to protect sensitive data by isolating it in a dedicated and secure area of a processor.

flashCards.title: Training Data
flashCards.definition: Dataset used to teach a ML model how to make predictions or perform tasks.

flashCards.title: Multimodal
flashCards.definition: AI systems or models that can process and understand information from multiple modalities, such as text, images, and sound.

flashCards.title: Scalable MatMul-free Language Modeling
flashCards.definition: Techniques in natural language processing that avoid matrix multiplication (MatMul) operations to improve scalability and efficiency.

flashCards.title: Policy Gradient
flashCards.definition: Class of algorithms in RL that optimizes the parameters of a policy directly through gradient ascent on expected future rewards.

flashCards.title: HMI (Human-Machine Interface)
flashCards.definition: Hardware or software through which humans interact with machines, facilitating clear and effective communication between humans and computer systems.

flashCards.title: Thermodynamic Bayesian Inference
flashCards.definition: Framework that draws an analogy between thermodynamics and Bayesian probability theory to infer statistical models by treating inference as an energy-minimizing process.

flashCards.title: Model Compression
flashCards.definition: Techniques designed to reduce the size of a machine learning model without significantly sacrificing its accuracy.

flashCards.title: Autoformalization
flashCards.definition: Process of automatically converting natural language descriptions or informal mathematical ideas into formal mathematical or logical expressions using AI.

flashCards.title: Dual Use
flashCards.definition: Technologies developed for civilian purposes that can also be repurposed for military or malicious applications, highlighting ethical considerations in their development and regulation.

flashCards.title: Image Synthesis
flashCards.definition: Use of AI models to generate new, unique images based on learned patterns and features from a dataset.

flashCards.title: Responsible AI
flashCards.definition: Application of AI in a manner that is transparent, unbiased, and respects user privacy and value.

flashCards.title: Anomaly Detection
flashCards.definition: Process of identifying unusual patterns that deviate from expected behavior, often used to detect fraud, network intrusions, or unusual transactions.

flashCards.title: Contextual BM25
flashCards.definition: Widely used probabilistic ranking function for assessing document relevance in search queries based on a bag-of-words model.

flashCards.title: Multi-Token Prediction
flashCards.definition: AI technique used in NLP where a model generates multiple output tokens simultaneously, often improving coherence and speed compared to single-token generation methods.

flashCards.title: Autoregressive Generation
flashCards.definition: Method where the prediction of the next output in a sequence is based on the previously generated outputs.

flashCards.title: AEO (Answer Engine Optimization)
flashCards.definition: Process of optimizing content to improve its chances of being selected as the direct response by search engines or voice assistants to user queries.

flashCards.title: Groundedness
flashCards.definition: Property of language models that ensures their generated content or interpretations are closely tied to or derived from real-world knowledge and contexts.

flashCards.title: Hyperdimensional Computing
flashCards.definition: An approach leveraging high-dimensional vector spaces and random hypervectors to build robust and efficient models for AI tasks.

flashCards.title: Function Approximator
flashCards.definition: Computational model used to estimate a target function that is generally complex or unknown, often applied in machine learning and control systems.

flashCards.title: Self-Speculative Decoding
flashCards.definition: Mechanism that predicts subsequent symbols in a sequence, enhancing prediction accuracy.

flashCards.title: BNN (Bispectral Neural Networks)
flashCards.definition: Utilize higher-order spectral features for improved signal processing and pattern recognition tasks, enhancing traditional neural network capabilities.

flashCards.title: Federated Training
flashCards.definition: Decentralized machine learning approach where multiple devices or nodes collaboratively train a shared model while keeping their data localized, rather than aggregating it centrally.

flashCards.title: Horizon
flashCards.definition: Length of the future over which decisions are considered, with long horizon involving many future steps and short horizon involving only a few.

flashCards.title: Spatial Autoencoder
flashCards.definition: A variant of autoencoder networks that leverages spatial information within data for efficient feature learning, often used in processing image and spatial data.

flashCards.title: ADAM (Adaptive Moment Estimation)
flashCards.definition: Algorithm for gradient-based optimization of stochastic objective functions, widely used in training DL models.

flashCards.title: Search Optimization
flashCards.definition: Process of enhancing algorithms' ability to efficiently search for the most optimal solution in a potentially vast solution space.

flashCards.title: Sampling Algorithm
flashCards.definition: Method used to select a subset of data from a larger set, ensuring that the sample is representative of the original population for the purpose of analysis or computational efficiency.

flashCards.title: Token Speculation Techniques
flashCards.definition: Strategies used in NLP models to predict multiple potential tokens (words or subwords) in parallel, improving the efficiency of text generation.

flashCards.title: Semantic Indexing
flashCards.definition: Structured representation of information that captures the meaning and relationships between concepts, enabling more effective search and retrieval of data based on the meaning of words rather than just keyword matches.

flashCards.title: Stochastic
flashCards.definition: Systems or processes that are inherently random, involving variables that are subject to chance.

flashCards.title: Self-Attention
flashCards.definition: Mechanism in neural networks that allows models to weigh the importance of different parts of the input data differently.

flashCards.title: Cross entropy loss
flashCards.definition: Loss function used to measure the difference between two probability distributions for a given random variable or set of events.

flashCards.title: Dualism
flashCards.definition: Theory or concept that emphasizes the division between symbolic (classical) AI and sub-symbolic (connectionist) AI.

flashCards.title: Negative Utilitarianism
flashCards.definition: Ethical theory that prioritizes minimizing suffering and negative experiences over maximizing happiness and positive experiences.

flashCards.title: Feed Forward
flashCards.definition: Essential structure of an artificial neural network that directs data or information from the input layer towards the output layer without looping back.

flashCards.title: Model Stability
flashCards.definition: Refers to the consistency and reliability of a machine learning model's performance when exposed to different subsets of data or slight variations in input.

flashCards.title: Geometric Deep Learning
flashCards.definition: Field of study that extends DL techniques to data that is structured as graphs, manifolds, or more general topological spaces.

flashCards.title: Curse of Dimensionality
flashCards.definition: Phenomenon where the complexity and computational cost of analyzing data increase exponentially with the number of dimensions or features.

flashCards.title: Ablation
flashCards.definition: Method where components of a neural network are systematically removed or altered to study their impact on the model's performance.

flashCards.title: Assistant
flashCards.definition: Software system designed to perform tasks or services for an individual, often leveraging NLP and ML to interact and respond intelligently.

flashCards.title: MLOps (Machine Learning Operations)
flashCards.definition: Practice of collaboratively combining ML system development and ML system operation, aiming for faster deployment and reliable management.

flashCards.title: Meta-Regressor
flashCards.definition: Type of ensemble learning method that uses the predictions of several base regression models to train a second-level model to make a final prediction.

flashCards.title: AI Effect
flashCards.definition: Phenomenon where once an AI system can perform a task previously thought to require human intelligence, the task is no longer considered to be a benchmark for intelligence.

flashCards.title: Parameter Space
flashCards.definition: Multidimensional space defined by all possible values of the parameters of a model, often used in ML and optimization to explore different configurations that influence model performance.

flashCards.title: EDL (Experimentation Driven Learning)
flashCards.definition: AI approach where learning algorithms improve their performance through systematic experimentation and feedback from the environment.

flashCards.title: Speed of Light Issues
flashCards.definition: Challenges or constraints in computing, communication, and physics that arise due to the finite speed at which light (and thus electromagnetic signals) travels.

flashCards.title: MAS (Multi-Agent System)
flashCards.definition: Software framework where several autonomous entities called agents interact to achieve individual or collective goals.

flashCards.title: Scalar
flashCards.definition: Single numerical value, typically representing a quantity or magnitude in mathematical or computational models.
